joowET5H59zoyYLGelqI-A.text: Love this place! so many fun rooms, amazing history, great ambiance. If I lived in London I would frequent here. It does get busy and can be difficult to maneuver after a few pints so its more of a casual drop in for me and not a night out type of place.

Dc2kIAOcJFH-xHpT2X8bNQ.text: Monopoly Pub Crawl - Stop #16 - Fleet Street (Red)Time to break into the red color group and what better place than Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese? This is my favourite pub on this crawl and is definitely not one to be missed. This is one of the oldest pubs in London, and as Ben Y said, it's in fact older than the USA. Yet despite its age, the Cheshire Cheese isn't a stodgy pub stuck in a different era, but rather a fairly vibrant seductive pub hidden in central London.The interior is segregated into a number of bars and seating areas which gives you quite a variety to choose from. We crowded into the beer bar area which offers a in house brew  that is light and hoppy (think Leffe) and quite delicious. You can also get your full range of Belgian and other top range beers. There are also some fruitier options for those that aren't partial to the bitter stuff.Dark wood panels cover the walls and are decorated with random bits that seem to be have been collected over the years. It gives you a feeling of calm and provides an oasis to relax after a busy day. Unfortunately, we had no such time and were off to the next one! But I'll definitely be back one day to really enjoy Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese as it deserves to be.

u-2KZDz6rWsX1Q5Pli7rdQ.text: Sorry to report that The place has fallen hard times. We stopped in fir a late lunch on a Saturdsy (1400hrs) and the staff was so rude and non service interested we left and went down the street.  Not worth a visit to eve darken its door.

ACNWQNPV-C5sJ7INMKQApQ.text: It does get a bit overrun by tourists at times, but the downstairs rooms have a great atmosphere and there's something to the place that keeps me coming back. Beer selection is ok, bar food is fine. I've eaten dinner there once, and thought it wasn't all that great. Four stars for the ambience and the history.

IcoZvDYfyLlKu6tO0IBNpw.text: Quite easily the coolest bar I've ever been to. This place was RE-built before America was a country - let that sink in for a moment. Grab a pint at one of the bars, and wander around to the various rooms, including the cave like carve out with extremely low ceilings.

oXXB3h4bH7LSz3Hx9X3Y1w.text: If you want to get a feel for real a London pub, there is no finer place. The signage is a dinky little lantern and the original doors and fixtures are great. They even have sawdust on the floor to keep the original feeling! a long list of the royals who have been in the monarchy whilst the pub has been there all adds to the overall ambiance. Its dark, it's small, its reasonably priced, though you couldn't be there too long, one drink is enough to soak up the atmosphere but a must see for out of towners!

fLoek8he4upqys2yBsBBYg.text: This is hands down my favorite pub in London, or better yet, my favorite pub EVER! Love the atmosphere with the multiple areas (with their own bartenders) for unwinding. I think what made this place unique is when we had to use the restroom that's in the basement and saw more stairs to head lower for more bar areas, and then it goes even lower and we are now drinking in a cave like area. This is the second oldest bar in London, so I figured it would be very touristy, but this to me, was my favorite relax spot for a pint or two or three.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

emFNIVRjb6U6R8J7qzaG4A.text: Went here for the first time in years. Had forgotten what a lovely place it is. Don't try and find a group of friends downstairs as you're mobile won't work and there's so many different areas you might find yourself hunting around to find each other. And I'd avoid stillettos if I where you, the floors are a bit of a nightmare. But have to say I'd forgotten what a lovely place this is!

U_DVrrI3KyjRNgxuxAmuyw.text: #513 Having dined at plenty of old and historic establishments, I wasn't blown away by the antiquated architecture of the Cheshire Cheese. Instead, I found that the short ceilings and tiny steps kick-started my vertigo. Seriously, walking down to the cellar, I was slightly concerned that I might tip over and fall straight down the stairs! But, of course, that's a personal problem that the Cheshire Cheese can't help. Regardless, I was surprised that food was only served down in the cellar during the lunch hour. But, Adam B. and I had no problems with that. We actually went straight for the largest table just because we were in need of some sprawling time. We had to wait a little while for the rest of our party to show up, but I got myself a nice, bottled ginger ale to sip on and enjoyed soaking in the authentic British aura that the bar oozed all over. Once we were ready to order, I walked over to the bar to get myself a Scampi entree. Unfortunately, they tack on a 1-2% card fee to cover the credit card company's charge. So, I ended up paying about 12gbp for the Scampi and a side order of Calamari. The bartenders were nice enough to bring our orders directly to us since we were sitting right in front of the bar and it didn't take too long. My Scampi was absolutely delicious. It was fresh and fried to the perfect crisp. I couldn't even finish all of it! The chips were also a crispy delight, but the salad left a little to be wanted. You had the usual tossings, but they added too much vinaigrette and I ended up picking around most of it. I wouldn't say no to a second order of the Scampi though. There were hardly any parties when we first got there, but over time the place started to fill up. People were clearly eyeing our table, so we finished up quickly and headed out. I say that this place is worth the visit for the historical factor, but otherwise, it's just your usual pub!

0QVFdoc1QUh-DV38QqRNIg.text: TOURIST TRAP. Sure the place looks charming-- but DO NOT eat here. Come, take your picture, have your beer and leave, ASAP. This was the WORST food I had in London. I ordered a "spicy chicken breast".. what I got were three chicken tenders with some fries and a few greens. It was just horrible. My husband ordered a burger, which was worse than an American school cafeteria meal. Also feels like a cafeteria since you basically serve yourself. Yep, pickup your food at counter and haul it to your table. Everyone in there had a backpack, which should have tipped us off.  Just awul.

2r9PrmnhKSCnHCPTxO8Y2Q.text: cute bar!everything in london is super expensive but not this bar! it's in a little alley, and has about five levels in the basement. looked like a dungeon but has character. we went about 5-6 ish so there's a lot of people just getting of work. lots of young people just having a good time. cheap beer and i liked the chicken mushroom pie.good stuff!

MBo7G9ByE3ob4T05QjSQ0A.text: We went to 3 Sam Smith Pubs.The ChandosAnchor TapYe Old Cheshire CheeseThere are about 40 Sam Smith Pubs. I wish we could have known about them the first day we there. For the most part they are very similar.First and foremost, their beer is great and very reasonably priced. My wife loved the Teddy Lager (she is more of Blue Moon type). I got the Extra Stout and it was excellent. I can see why the English drink so much.Second, we fell in love with a dessert called Sticky Toffee Pudding. The locals get the pudding topping but we went with the ice cream. The size of the scoop of the ice cream did vary from pub to pub.Third, was the food. We tried different items each time (except we did order the Fisherman's pie and Bangers & Mash twice). The food was ok. Nothing special. The fish on the Fish & Chips were good but the Chips were not crisp. I would recommend getting regular peas instead of the Mushy Peas. I thought they would taste similar but they don't.In all the pubs you order at the bar and sometimes you pick up your own food and sometimes they bring it to you. Could be it depends on how busy it is.The service in all the places were very good and the female bar keepers were very friendly.

ARnIbHQHM5vVykHwlJAlYQ.text: Perhaps I'm generous with this review, as this was the first decent meal I've had in London (two days in). But I thought this place was quite solid, and central to many of the offices in the City.Per the other reviews, I went down to the basement bar (down some series of levels and twists and turns -- at least two floors below street level) to grab dinner and beers. Sure, many of the accents I heard were American or otherwise foreign -- but London is a global financial hub, after all. I ordered a Shepherd's Pie, which came with fries and veggies, and a pint of the extra stout house beer. Both were quite good, and the total for both was GBP 9.65. Not bad, for this area of the city. I went back for a chocolate pudding and a pint of cider, and the total for that was GBP 6.95 (mainly due to the higher price of cider vs. stout). The chocolate pudding with custard was actually really awesome -- quite memorable, and a great deal at GBP 2.70. The bar is unpretentious, the service decent, the decor interesting, and the buzz is quite nice. I'm sure I'll be back before I leave London.

1-6_LXEqkOCCYOVNnd0qcw.text: Have you ever heard the phrase "Polly wants a cracker"?  Well, if the story I heard from the bartender is true, it was invented here.As we sat drinking our many pints of Samuel Smith's various ales and talking with a couple of scots we met (who bought us many of those pints), my friend inquired about the stuffed bird in the glass case above the bar.  Apparently, back in the day, (way back) many of London's journalists and writers would drink there and they taught that bird, Polly, all manner of dirty phrases.  One of the favorites apparently was "What will you have to drink?"  Polly would respond with "I'd like a scotch."  Apparently, Walt Disney visited and heard the story.  At that point, he decided to make Polly a part of Pirates of the Caribbean and thus "polly wants a cracker" was born.The Polly story is the only introduction that you need for this place.

Mb0uXrmH3CxUw4_F_GEYxg.text: In light of the 2012 Olympics, I've decided to review some places in London that I've tried out to help our fellow travelers find places to eat with that traditional British flair. I found Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese Pub on Yelp, as a devoted follower I was happy to see that this place had a lot of character to it. It is one of the oldest pubs in England rebuilt in 1667 as it burned down in the London Fire so you can trust you will really get a feel of cultural England in this place. Dark and kind of dimly lit with wood that has warped through the ages this pub, like The Blue Anchor, is a pub out of time. A pub that has been frequented by old English author Samuel Johnson, and perhaps more famously Charles Dickens, this pub gives you a feel and taste of old English HistoryThe food here is relatively good, staying true to the traditional British foods, there are plenty of helpings of traditional roast beef with Yorkshire pudding, lamb shank, and roast pheasant. The food is excellently prepared with a heaping helping of potatoes on the side. The food was well cooked, most came with a lovely gravy. The man serving us was an elderly man who seemed to be very happy to help and incredibly knowledgeable about the pub itself. Overall, not a bad choice. I, myself, am not a fan of traditional British food but if you're looking for a cultural experience and a pub with character I would recommend Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese. It is small and the dining room is a bit small and cramped. There are several rooms separated for the pub and a eating area, and a restaurant so make sure you're in the right place. It is a Samuel Smith Pub so it only serves that specific brand of Beer and Cider. All in all, a good restaurant with a Doctor Who time traveling feel. It is, a pub that truly has stood through the ages and earns the albeit hokey title of "Ye Olde."

P48_K4btx4ILcFDXegNKrA.text: This is the second time I have eaten here and both times were great fun.  This is the most interesting restaurant I have ever eaten in.  In reality it is multiple restaurants in one.  Every section is a different menu and motif.  Last year we ate at the upscale section, this year we ate in the basement pub.  The most confusing part of the entire restaurant is that each area has its own hours.The food is consistently good and the service was excellent.  We had beef shepherds pie on our last visit and it was very good.  Last year we had fish & chips and I forgot what else.The entrance is tucked away in an alley so you have to keep your eyes open for the little signs.

iHJc4mrxBmvx3teMMI-yLg.text: Had to make a stop here, heard it was the oldest pub in London still in operation.  Cool old building.  We got a table way downstairs.  Had a few drinks and I went with the fish and chips.  Chips were perfect, crispy on the outside soft inside.  Fish was just good.  A little greasy (but then again, fried, is fried) great for the atmosphere, "rebuilt in 1667" that place has seen some things!

qXvfp8Cb6tc96SL6DOpi0w.text: This pub deserves 5 stars not because it is on a technical level the best pub, with the best seating and dining arrangements and the best choice of beer and ale. This pub deserves it because it represents a time capsule of an era really long lost, of an easy going culture, with a dark and dingy atmosphere of the Victorian times and before, which although doesn't seem like not something to be romanticised about in our electronic age, but yet is something we search for all the time - to be secluded in a hole engrossed in our own thoughts without being barged in upon constantly by notifications. That very feeling is there in this pub, unchanged in its dark wooden surroundings, an almost Gothic feel captured like a photograph, and all this, even though it has fewer seats than one would like, making it quite frustrating to visit it on a sunny afternoon. The beer/ales are good, and on future visits, will try out the food as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Look up to find this as you enter the bar area.

d_R8lOIPNzYHa8UCWKHa0w.text: Very good pub in the city Of London.  Great atmosphere,  Can be a little touristy.  Good food.

cEpc9CjCCsa6ernKdUemWQ.text: Didn't eat here as it was a Friday night and very busy. Great little pub. Many nooks and different levels/areas to hang out in. The Samuel Smith beers are very good. Couldn't get a seat anywhere but thoroughly enjoyed drinking at the different bars within the pub.

_q0LOuQ-nhBuWRdXSUXLFg.text: Loved the history, but too crowded, too loud when crowded, and to our dismay, a more limited beer selection upstairs (the only place we could find a seat).  Did not eat here.  I get some people like shoulder to shoulder pubs full of noise.  Not me.

yAUWlEdM0PKAuwNSe7fIxA.text: I couldn't not go here since it's the oldest pub in London. Like Suki B. said, I loved everything about this pub.I liked:1) How it's in an alleyway off a main street2) How there are like 3 bars/dining rooms3) How the walls are all dark old wood4) How the ceiling is low in some doorways5) How they serve amazing draught beers from a cask6) How the fish and chips were exceptional7) How the mac and cheese had a British twist I've never tasted (it's called Cheshire Cheese)8) How it wasn't crazy busy when I went in the late afternoon9) How the prices are very reasonable (like £2 for a brew)10) How lots of locals actually go here and doesn't seem like a tourist trapWith these things said, I highly recommend coming here not only because of the history, but because of the great atmosphere and yummy food. The fish and chips were great but not the best I've had. Get the mac and cheese for sure. At the least, you must grab a beer and wonder which random famous British people sat where you are sitting.

PG6tjerFVGfijc7nTzbzPA.text: Went here with coworkers due to it being taunted as the oldest pub in central London. The beer is good- all Samuel smiths. Service was quick and friendly. I really enjoyed the different, very unique rooms that were throwbacks in decor and materials to when such people as Dickens actually drank and wrote here. Another famous celeb is the parrot from "Polly want a cracker" fame...he can be found stuffed and on a shelf in the first room after entering the place. Also loved that there were a few fireplaces with coals burning warmly in some of the rooms. All in all a very neat, very cool pub. Although a bit touristy (I was a tourist more or less, so not complaining!), still comfortable to have a few pints with friends, and maybe write a novel or two while there as well. Also, try the fried cheese, it is fantastic!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Ye olde Cheshire cheese

ryUSxtPdVGkaYd8HS8mqQg.text: Cool pub tucked into a small alley off Fleet Street.  We came here under a recommendation from a friend.  The atmosphere is friendly and relaxed.There are a number of levels and rooms tucked away so it may come across as quite the maze.  We ended up in the lower cellar floor.  Be careful of your head as you duck down to go to the lower levels.Service was good and the Steak and Ale Pie even better.  I ordered the Organic Wheat Beer which I loved.  My hubby ordered a number of different lagers--all good.A definite must try if you are in the area!

MgndRn_SSFJEjf6oNCwjXw.text: I just love the history of this bar. Many levels of caverns and places to hide and drink. I felt transported in time. Also Samuel Smith beer is excellent!

kzr_kisz2HvBM9tgQ4besA.text: found this place during a recent visit to London.  Great beers and fish & chips.  Would come back again next time I'm in London.

tSJvXczk9Dht6j4-kg-XfQ.text: This stop was a highlight on our trip to London.We read about it in the Frommers guidebook and hit it on a weekend afternoon. Surprisingly, there were very few people there. The service at the downstairs bar was fast and friendly.We LOVED the cozy, unique "drinking rooms." That we were drinking a pint where Charles Dickens once drank was a fact that thrilled my husband. The fish and chips were fantastic, the  chicken pie went over very well with my kids, and the custard did not disappoint.We should have gone back a second time. Really, truly a highlight.

HX8pjjBcwsauM-ZpvDOSJg.text: Literature nerd alert!! One of the oldest pubs in London, Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese was the drinking establishment of choice for famous writers. Legend has it that Charles Dickens wrote A Tale of Two Cities here, W. B. Yeats threw down some poetry, and even Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was inspired by a proper pint of Ale. The very environment of the pub arouses one's creativity. With dim lights, low entryways, and a fascinating labyrinth-like layout it is no wonder authors were driven to write. Although they don't really have a great selection of pints, their ales were creamy and tasty and certainly offered a greater variety of Samuel Smith beers than we're used to in the states. As a good little tourist I had the fish and chips with mushy peas, and my wife had the steak and ale pie. As my first meal in London, it did not disappoint! The fish was crispy, tarter sauce tangy, and the pie was meaty and flavorful.A truly magnificent place with friendly bartenders and a rich history.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Fish and chips and steak and ale pie

ZoZUjmNj_bVpO9KsIr_UXA.text: Great pub for the atmosphere and drinks. We didn't try the food and kids aren't allowed in the evening so we couldn't stay long with our boys, but highly recommended stopping by for a pint.

3wPD-APoBJUHPT3egNbgzQ.text: Loved everything about this pub - it's one of the oldest pubs in London, which made the experience even better. Located on Fleet Street, keep your eyes peeled when looking for this place. It's tucked away in an alley and can be easily missed. We walked right past the alley a few times before finally finding it. There are three levels, you have to take a flight of really tricky stairs to go to each. You literally have to hunch down to get through - I hit my head going back up when we were leaving, so be extra careful. We went down to the 2nd level and found some seats. The place is really charming. Loved the ambiance - it's dark and candle-lit, but still very lively. Definitely felt historic. As we sat down, there was a huge group of Brits trickling in for what seemed like a family reunion; they were having an awesome time. It kind of felt like we were watching a British movie, haha! You seat yourself and to grab drinks and food, you have to go down to the basement level, which was my absolute favorite. Sadly, it was way too packed, so we couldn't find a seat down there. Their fish & chips were DELICIOUS! Just what I had been searching for. Definitely the best I had during my trip and believe me, I tried it at several popular places.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. The middle room.
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. The entrance is in an alleyway. You'll miss it if you don't pay attention!
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Hands-down the best fish & chips I had while in London!

vyU3RN_m4gj0ZhPpN4nEHw.text: I'm going to be honest - I totally went here because of the awesome name. Then I found out about the history of this landmark pub and was even more delighted. We were seated in the cozy corner, which was this really cute little corner surrounded by curtains. Service was fine. We had the cheese plate and the goat cheese salad (had to go with cheese, given the name). The salad was just ok - small serving & not much of a salad to speak of, just some lettuce surrounding the cheese. Cheese plate was also quite small, but the cheese selection was ok. The cider, however, was lovely. Would recommend this place for its ambiance and drinks selection, but would not order food again.

yzf4M0gDAlxUpxWyH2toaw.text: It's not everyday that you get to eat and drink in a pub whose history predates that of the establishment of the United States. Rebuilt in 1667 after the Great Fire, this historic pub can claim Charles Dickens and Mark Twain among its former patrons. Everything from the alleyway entrance to the winding stairs leading to multiple basement levels gives you the sense that Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is from a different era.We settled in the basement, which resembled more of a dungeon, for lunch. Wanting to get a taste of traditional pub fare, I couldn't turn down trying ye famous steak and kidney pie. The flavor of kidney overpowered the steak and pretty much anything else on the plate. It was then that I realized that I'm not a fan of kidney. On the other hand, the fish & chips were outstanding. But, it would have been nice to see them have some homemade tartar sauce rather than have them in packets. All the specials are £8 and most of the main courses are £5-6, which makes this pub quite the affordable place to eat. The portions are also quite large so the half pints of beer or cider are perfect with the meals.

66QUrYxMzfSHrs6SogWZWw.text: I think for the pure historical aspect of it, this place gets five stars from me, hands down.I also think I must be the WEIRDEST person they have ever encountered, ever. I came here on a rainy day when I was wandering around London by myself. I had gone to a couple of places early in the morning and managed to check off a ton of things on my list including an awesome little coffee spot that I found near this area to have a sit down, legitimate, cup of joe - complete with latte art and all.When I showed up here, it was tipping 11:30am. I was pretty much the only person in here because they had opened at 11am. The lunch service was not available until 12, and I had other places to be on my crazy whirlwind tour. So of course, I sat down at the bar, and ordered a beer.Yup. 11:30am. On a Monday. I did that. And guess what, IT WAS AWESOME.The beer was actually quite delicious, and sort of refreshing as I gazed outwards on this rainy day in London. The inside had this musty but comforting smell to it, like something familiar and safe. There was a nice fire place, but unfortunately it wasn't that warm. The bartender was more than happy to make conversation while I took DSLR shots of my single little beer, but alas I was done in less than 10 minutes. Still, great place, I wish I could come back when it was more happening!

OfPD734P81a2UYdGqJFpbA.text: I can't say much for its beer, ale, etc., but the food wasn't all too great.  Portions are small and the place gets insanely crowded.  I can't help but feel that this is another tourist trap.  In fact, at one point 3 out of the 4 tables around us were occupied by tourists from the US.  So...message to my fellow USA citizens, again, I can't speak of the EtOH, but the food here is just okay, nothing worthy of it's 4 star rating.  Plenty of good fish and chips and steak pie  establishments back home.  Perhaps, we go because of our love for Charlie...

rb21j8iFqETVZsk8cVfCzg.text: I love this place. It's like 5 or 6 floors, most of them underground via narrow, crooked steps. Very good fish and chips, oodles of beer. Order at the bar. Find your own table. It was crowded in the early evening on a week night. Lots of locals! I highly recommend a visit to this historic pub. Mark Twain and Charles Dickens like the place, so did I.

djIsdCC14bRjjDsrRFZbmg.text: Oldest pub in London. Stopped in for a pint in one of the rooms. Crazy to think how long the pub has been open and operating. Not much more to the experience for us than that.

bZ8NI6Ueoxpix46uue36kw.text: I had an old car once that caught on fire in a freak accident. I still needed a car, so I replaced it. Now, I sometimes still refer to my 2011 vehicle as the "new" car, and the now-no-longer-in-existence vehicle as the "old" one.My "old" car, if I still drove it, would be more than 330 years newer than the "new" incarnation of the Cheshire Cheese pub. The "new" bar, only 110 years old, is in the cellar.A place like this would be worth checking out just for the history, but to have a place like this on Fleet Street that was NOT setting out to gouge tourists made our visit even more special. Prices were actually quite reasonable, the staff was very friendly and welcoming, and the kidney pie and local ale made for a nice stop in London. We saw enough locals in the cellar bar playing cards, chatting and drinking, that I could almost see another life if ancestors hundreds of years back hadn't bailed.A fantastic place to visit and grab a pint.

zMITjy8oORn3kvknRxxkbw.text: Went to Ye Old Cheshire Cheese last night and had the starters and the fish and chips (battered fish cod). The starters was a bit of a mix, but the pie (tart?) was really good. Recommendable. The fish and chips was really good. Especially the fish was nicely made. The chips/fries were a little old school (like free way cafeteria soft), and I would have preferred them more crispy.

aKLO3i_7L8RgqUL14ygNtQ.text: My wife and I ducked in this pub after visiting St Paul.  What a cool place!  Unfortunately we weren't hungry but there is something great about having a beer in a pub rebuilt in 1667 after the fires.

Dsag-iaIYpQQA5ZS790bQg.text: Beer is great, ambiance is great. Food in the dining room however is bad. I think they made it in the morning and just reheated. Everything was either cold or overcooked.

binNbykfQJglDONRXaB68Q.text: Absolutely one of my favorite spots in London to grab a quick drink. The beer and food are both good and are reasonably priced, a rarity in my experience, and for a history lover like myself, the atmosphere can't be beat!

CSu-_BG30NXe3_O4x_J_5Q.text: This place is so touristy but I like it.  I think I drank the best organic wheat beer I've ever had here (but I was incredibly thirsty when I got in!) The restaurant food was pretty good too.  Prices are ok for a London tourist-type pub... they serve both a sit down menu and typical pub food (which would be a little cheaper if you're looking for value).  I thought it was a good find.

67R-mFci4WGp0G5TDT694w.text: I have a love-hate relationship with the Cheese. Yes, it is nice and ye oldey-worldey, and yes the beer is nice and cheap, but something about it makes me consider it a definite back-up pub. It lacks a certain je ne c'est pas for me.

M-FxpkVI_pbj5BEuU592fw.text: From the toasty fire in the tiny front bar to the cavernous collection of subterranean rooms, Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is a worthy experience. I'm a big fan of the Sam Smith's bitter from the cask and my girlfriend loves the pure brewed lager. The chips are thick cut, resembling steak fries in the US, and go perfectly with liberal doses of vinegar and salt. The Dickensian aura of Cheshire Cheese is tangible; a big plus for history buffs. The barkeeps are personable and funny, calling cantankerous customers wankers with aplomb. Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is a good fit for visitors of all stripes.

7ROQWiDEoJP1dfIJI2PjDQ.text: I love this old place too.  It is full of atmosphere, and history.  My first visit was in 1966, when I was served a wonderful beef and mushroom pie on a Wedgewood plate.  The Wedgewood is long gone, and so is the good food, but Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is still a great place for a pint.

6oZ0yCTlHcKe9EuqWcyokA.text: One of the best pubs in the city.  Best thing about the place is sitting in the cellar (watch your head on the way down) along side the picture of Mr. Johnson.  Great history, Samuel Smith beers and quality food.

hpdaPCR2pEQ_LB3oZzRxXA.text: This was my second favorite pub in England. A bit off the main path but nonetheless worth our time. Be aware that there are multiple rooms each with its own menu. Watch out the bartender on room to the right will direct you to wait for a table in the room to the left...keep walking through the corridor, there are other places to eat within the same pub! As a Charles Dickens fan, I enjoyed every moment of this place. Its hard to imagine eating in a room older than anything standing in the USA. Highly recommend a visit.

F8OUmYJMhQZltzn2Vph5GQ.text: This historic pub is fantastic.  I love the small spaces and the architecture, the beer and cider is cold, and the food is great by any standard.   We had lunch in the basement.  It was crowded, but it wasn't too loud.  There wasn't a wait for a table, and we were able to get our food quickly.  On my next visit to London, I'll definitely return here.

ppB_0qOF9_uiDwOf0zifYQ.text: Oh, the Cheese. How I miss my old local. Great history (don't miss the charred rafters on the lowest floor that took their scar in the great fire), great beer selection, friendly service, and surprisingly good traditional fare.

lIamneKW9zQVnbL4qQ3WPg.text: Widely regarded as the oldest and best pub in London, a title of which it thoroughly deserves. Being a Samuel Smith's pub it has a limited range of drinks, but one pint of the Alpine larger at a very cheap price, and you will not mind. The dark and dank interior is something not too dissimilar to a Harry Potter film, and really gives an excellent old world ambience to this pub. Truly my favourite pub in London.

OrUTuNmUWJoeJrE9povKAw.text: Funky interior, can get you spinning even before you hit the bar. Not exceptional amount of beers to choose from but the price is unbeatable for Central London. Food is OK, on the level you expect to find in a pub.

xDPvRxhNPzN4HWjQKEYEfw.text: Love this bar!  Historic ... sit in Johnson's seat and feel histroy (he wrote the dictionary) ... go to the deepest part of the pub to hang in some old, I think 1100's spots and do take time to eat up stairs (street level) as the food is good.

7CKXImIUkgQpWbmVz6QqTg.text: A lovely olde pub full of history and great food too! Well worth a visit with friends. There are lots of rooms to choose from but a word of warning re the stairs and how dark it is although that's no criticism, as it should be expected. The first room you see as you enter is on your right-hand side. This is more of a bar really and usually has a lovely fire going. A few other places can be drafty but just as charming. I have only visited during lunch so cannot comment on the evening but I know they have lots of tourists visit and private parties at Christmas. Check it out.

GLQwIPJIg4U6JhNNoBd2iQ.text: This pub was too warm and crowded on a winter mid-afternoon.  The pints were sloppy and not very cold, and the fish and chips were limp as if they'd been under a heat lamp for half an hour.  The pub is in a nice building and has great decor, but the rest of the experience is lackluster at best.

TR-r4dXpvx5ldXGaozYrww.text: Nice little place and very friendly beer good get full and why not great little pub

71Yxef5CrbjK2JmA3S4edw.text: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is a 17th century pub/restaurante down a narrow alleyway off Fleet Street with an atmospheric darke woodene interior, selling ye olde greate foode and ye olde greate beere. Highly recommended.

LoNH0-LsDM6G1Qj_q5G9yQ.text: Great pub, a very traditional feel to it, but I can't help but feel a bit sad that it's a Sam Smiths. Nowt wrong with that, but if they served a series of guest ales and put a bit more effort into the food it'd be a 5-star job.

5_Q_8geA2XRWeQuUYAoxhA.text: A gem, particularly so considering that it's in such a busy part of town. The pub is perfect for winter evenings. Service and selection of beers are ok, the real plus point is the fact the pub feels hidden away. Has a very Olde Worlde look, which could be tacky, but it works. Worth having a wander in the back streets off this side of Fleet or around the Inns of Court to the south either before or after your beers.

S6WBCCZqAXSoFC9Cdded_A.text: Such a privilege to work near this ancient pub. It's a fantastic old building and really puts you in mind of what London used to look like - if you ignore all the modern buildings and brands around it!! It's a bit disconcerting sometimes to find whole tourist groups being directed in for the 'Ye Oldie London' experience. It sells good food for lunch in the basement but there are more formal dining rooms which I've yet to sample.

q6uiY_pc-Cn26TmWeFa9Eg.text: This is the coolest pub I have been to in London. Inside is maze-like with what seems like 5 or 6 different different levels, each with their own seperate bar. It is filled with nooks and crannies and edges. This is a very different, definitely quirky place to hang out and have a beer

0sqBDsINI-slTn-HKWmRGw.text: I love the Cheshire Cheese. It is always a place I take my dates. I was recommended it by someone who works nearby. I don't drink as I don't want a beer gut but I only go there for the cosiness of the cellars, enjoy the history and to play a quiet game of cards. It has a nice atmosphere although tourists are flocking to it now, and gets too crowded in other bars. I wish it wasn't on the tourist trail.

uiTRN8IxnkN1CikCeog7iw.text: You can almost *feel* the history wandering lost through the twists and corridors at this ancient pub.  The only stronger feeling was that of indigestion after daring to eat the bar food.  Looked nice, tasted like every stereotype of bad British cuisine.  Still, this place is old and cool with lots of nooks to hide out in and interesting spaces.  The staff was super friendly, and I will totally come back to have a few pints again some time.  Be sure to duck when you visit the loo!

qitSIe3veK3CSY9_la-4VA.text: Despite the traditionally cheap brewery owner increasing its prices, this remains a gem.  Try and forget the hordes of toursists (including some organised groups) that descend on the place, and enjoy the rabbit warren of cellars and tiny hide aways.  Beautiful, historic and at times incredibly busy.  Worth treking across London to get to

sGr5JnyXz1A-99OL3yHrXg.text: Hiding in a tiny alleyway half way down Fleet Street, Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is a rare treat. It's cheap, being Sammy Smith's and all, and you feel like you're in a little miniature world. I suppose, back in the day, everyone was smaller, so pubs only needed to be this big. These days, it's a tight squeeze, but get your elbows in, and find a place at one of the bars, and you'll get served soon enough. When you get sick of the being hemmed in/too hot, walk down to The Old Bank of England, a Fuller's ale and pie house a short hop from here and get yourself a pint of Discovery to freshen up.

sYQR2gxflm2Una1J_xDnRA.text: I think you could call this the best pub in London, although it may be a little modern for some tastes, being rebuilt in 1667. I might be a few years off. As you can imagine, this pub is straight out of an episode of Blackadder or the pages of Dickens, who I'm sure drank here since all the writers did, including, famously, Dr Johnson. This is a Samuel Smiths pub, so the beer is the cheapest and best in London. Their cheapest pint is £1.80 (yorkshire bitter)and the most expensive bottle is £3.50 (oatmeal stout i think). There is brilliant food served in every bar (steak and kidney pud will finish you off) and if you can manage to get a seat in the tiny restaurant (no bookings) you can enjoy pheasant for a tenner! Mind you don't chomp on a bit of shot though. Smiths make their own spirits, so their shorts and mixers are cheap as well. The upstairs bits are reserved for private bookings, and are very nice indeed, and the fantastic cellar bar is closed on the weekends, but after a couple of pints, which should cost less than a fiver (in central London!) you won't care. Particularly if you're sat next to the real coal fire.

Eskn7XxiUDEyaJBVRmyIoA.text: This is a great little pub tucked in a tiny back street along Fleet Street. Dark and cosy with numerous caverns to eat and drink, it definitely has a lot more character than your standard pub. The pies are great and for £5.50 you can make a meal of it which includes a potato side (chips or mash), and either mushy peas, beans or salad. Although good value, it can be a bit hit and miss, with the last time I was there just under a month ago, there were huge lumps of partially cooked potato that had not been mashed properly - really put me offbut then again at least they are using real potato and not that packet mash I suppose. Judge for yourself and head down there if you're in the area.

fxtX6iiFu4m7qUXl7_uBTw.text: Came to eat here on a trip as your typical American tourist. Despite all of the old decorations and seats, which some might find boring, I think it's very neat. Also, the food tastes good, and that's all that matters.

9HH9dWWTeiDPX6xufH-yVQ.text: Wood chippings. On the floor. The first thing you can imagine as you enter the unassuming door in the side alley off Fleet Street, is that this is a very traditional pub, with one excellent facet to it. However - if that's all you imagine, you're aiming too low. This pub has so many facets it's a veritable engagement rock. The key to this pub is that there is an element to satisfy nearly all types of pub clientele. There is a small snug to the right of the entrance that feels like it was designed for village regulars. To the left, there is a pub restaurant area. Straight ahead, and it's a standard pub - mostly standing room only, long bar running along one wall. But it doesn't stop there. Upstairs there is a cosy boothed restaurant area that puts you in mind of Noel Coward's Still Life (latterly the movie Brief Encounter). Each booth has coat hooks on the outside, and you could almost imagine yourself conducting an illicit liaison on the Orient Express. Downstairs and you are back in time again, as the Cheese has converted some of it's old cellars into more seating area - with low, arched ceilings and warm lighting. Descend further and you are in the lowest bar, with long benches, stone flooring and whitewashed walls. I'm a big fan of Sam Smiths - and while I haven't had any issues with short pints - I can't recall the bar staff being particularly friendly or attentive. In fact, on one occasion it felt like I was being ignored. That aside - it is a lovely pub - and the staff problems are all fixable. I'll give this place 4 stars - only to encourage folk to visit here at least once. It's a bit of history, and an awesome place to be able to tell folk Yup - I know that pub..

3LAmERHlh4rxxy_2s21beQ.text: If you like the pub scene this is the place for you.  Three different areas to drink and the cellar to eat. Pub grub mostly. Nice environment.

6jxHMAgJ0WLEARKPbOuXRg.text: Yea, it's got loads of history, character and the Lagers are really good, but that's about it. Food isn't great, service isn't great, it gets really crowded in the small cave-like spaces, it's not the most comfortable place, but it's still worth taking some visitors to, just to let them know what a really old pub with loads of history looks like.

pM3vkzeZVqbaz65FLcfVXA.text: This place probably shouldn't work, ticking (as it does) every cliche in the 'olde worlde pub' book going. It's got the nooks and crannies, the old framed copperplate writing histories on the wall, the low ceilings, the timber frames - the works. And given what that normally means for London (crass tourist rip-off job) it is something of a surprise that Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is such a good pub. The atmosphere is always lively (but kept friendly by the intimacy of the many areas); the staff have got a real buzz about them and provide quick, efficient service; the beers are cheap, varied and in tune with the surroundings (Sam Smiths); the food (served mainly in a more formal area on ground level) is simple pub-grub but typically delicious and without the 'straight out of a microwave' taste you often encounter in London pubs.

bNn2-LfuJILs7YwE8mkBZw.text: Cracking pub, good atmosphere, good (and very cheap) beer, good central location and plenty of history to the place. I would put this in the category of pubs I would go out of my way to visit as well as very good pubs that are near places that everyone generally visits. If you get a chance go to the cellar bar downstairs (sometimes it's not open on weekends).

51g5lywJdHi4it_84HY8DA.text: This is one olde pub. While in London, my wife and I wanted to visit some olde haunts of infamous Londoners and Ye (the) Olde Cheshire Cheese is a must see. This place was built one year AFTER the great fire in 1666. However the pub was there a hundred years before that! The staff was very friendly, a rare treat in London. The food was really good too, very unexpected. It's pretty traditional fare so don't go ording a pizza or cheeseburger. My wife ordered the fish & chips and I got the kidney pudding, which was outstanding. The ambience is delightful and rich of history, you can literally feel the history of this place. Gorgeous woodwork and original stained glass windows are located throughout. This place has multiple levels so be sure to take a little tour. Besides having good food, great ambiance, and having a pint with Dr. Samuel Johnson, this place is OLDE school. They still heat the dining room with coal, which accounts for the smokey atmosphere. A must see while in London.

t_SlcQxWQdY_rIan7sMjZA.text: Love Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese! Always take family & friends there when in London - great bit of history! And the food I think is very good I know it's a bit of a tourist trapbut at least the staff are friendly and there are so many little rooms up and downstairs, always somewhere to go!Recommend the fish & chips!

IsmMPSMpMSkdL8khM8SIMw.text: I have only been to the Cheshire Cheese a few times over the years, it's always good to go back to. As others have noted the prices are good for central London, and the atmosphere positively leaks out of the fabric of the building. Yanks do seem to like the place for it's age and history, but I like it for that too, even as a well travelled and somewhat world weary Brit. This is a good stop if you are poking around the backwaters of the City and Inns of Court as a tourist, and I definitely try to take people in who haven't been before as most everybody likes the place. Highly recommended.

Chx8TCZI1CVrKQUczMX0TA.text: Well, I was going to write something wonderful about the history of this place, but seems I've been beaten to it. Just three stars from me too, but not because of the pouring technique of the staff (who I also found very friendly, but could do with a little more bar-queue awareness. As mentioned the original burnt down in the great fire of London, however I suspect the only room to survive was the gents toilet - that's the only reason I can come up with to explain the stench.. Otherwise, a nice enough place with a bit of a barn feel to it..

iNz4JnQHuTJkfh8GS0fDRA.text: This pub was built in 1667. It goes down for what feels miles below the surface of London. And its probably the most fun place you'll ever drink. The cosy layout of this pub, with snugs, mini-bars and myriad tiny rooms, allow for intimate meetings and nice, friendly get-togethers. I have enjoyed multiple university parties in here, and many more quiet pints with a friend. The clientele are both Fleet Street workers, and King's College students, along with a smattering of regulars who look like they've been coming in since the pub was built. Staff are friendly and efficient, and the Alpine beer is exactly what you'd expect: Cheap and refreshing. The food isn't all that, just your typical pub fare, fish and chips and some pies; but the atmosphere is so snug and happy that although you come for the cheer, you will stay for the food. Pint of Alpine £1.98; Fish and chips about £7.

0KaU6pUcrccnAH5ZCwNoig.text: 700 year old cellars and 1.99 pints! It  was my favorite pub on my vacation in London. The bartender there at the time was super friendly too.

yX6VJ8BaxLSN9zxq2qiHZQ.text: Some times I love this place and sometimes being in there is just painful (quite literally if you hit your head on the low ceilings).  This is a great winter pub but in the summer it's not that great being stuck underground.The Cheshire can get really crowded - especially on payday when it seems most of the city are there, which is what I refer to on the painful front (low ceilings aside).  Most Thursdays and Fridays though there's a good crowd of people in and the atmosphere's good.  It's a good place to go with a group of work mates for a couple, maybe before moving on elsewhere.The best thing, history aside, has to be the drinks.  There's no branded drinks, which is quite cool, as it's all their own brands which are really good and the price is excellent for a city pub.Definatley one to have a beer or two in if your on Fleet Street.

hqchEjzUETuuvhV0yUbdvw.text: Came here on a recommendation from a friend. Loved the maze-like ancient space and decor. Very Old-London. Beers were great, service was nice. Fish and chips were eh. Skin was still on (blech) and it was oozing frying oil. Like way too much. Chips were nice. Redeeming factor was the divine sticky toffee pudding. Served with custard as God intended man to serve it.

w7ZKP12TNY-N7xnuj1gkAw.text: Amazing place, with so much history in it. High quality beers, great service, reasonable prices, and the hidden entry made of this bars one of my favorites.You have formal and informal meals, tables for two and tables for big crowds.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

pfztiVQ46tRKz8NDe2SGqw.text: Lovely old English pub. No, it really is old. It has lots of charm and best of all, it's reasonably priced. You may want to mind your head in this place though, you may struggle a bit if you're particularly tall. You should venture downstairs, I've never been to a pub quite like it. The staff were actually very friendly and it was great that the person we spoke to working behind the bar had so much knowledge on the history of the pub.

e_1Dzpjst25y3d8W7SGQyw.text: We ordered the house steak, the sausage trio, and another dish that was almost the same as the house steak... The food was alright, but felt a bit boring. It wasn't bad, but I felt that the flavors could have been a little more pronounced. I have had better English food, but I suppose most English food is somewhere along the same line of excitement. Not horrible, but I wouldn't be back for the food.The environment was very nice and cozy though! We sat in a booth with walls that went up pretty high so we got a lot of privacy and it was a unique experience.

FC0KIMfTrBSjVDpbRBiUjw.text: Loved this place!   Charles Dickens used to drink here among other famous writers.   Food was very good, service was great upstairs in the dining room off the side of the entrance.   It's been around since the 1600's.

Mcu19DwOOh-z0C6gjoFV2w.text: One thing I must wonder about this pub is how many tourists must walk through the door because of how famous it is.  I get paranoid because then I start wondering, "Is it good enough to be something even locals would visit?"  Obviously, I can't really say since I am one of the tourists to visit, but I had a decent enough experience at this pub to appreciate it.After being told this is one of the older and more well known pubs to still be open in London, my travel buddy and I went for lunch for the stereotypical fish and chips.  Pretty standard fare in my opinion.  The fish: good; the chips: good; the peas: good.  What I found was that the main reasons I liked this place was because of the location and fruit beers.   The overall feel of this place was charming and a bit dark, but honestly, it's very lovable.  With a couple of floors to accommodate guests, we ended up in the basement level to eat.   I only saw a few other people so it's probably not very crowded in comparison to other tourist spots, but we went at lunch, so that may be why.  I ordered one of the Sam Smith fruit beers, and while I normally hate beers in general, I really liked this one.  Surprisingly light and subtlety sweet.  I think this place is worth checking out for its history and location.  The beers were good as well but I only wish I was blown away by its food too!

MBQ_kL5990oxggwQNM3kuw.text: Dropping with history on every level. Great beers, fish & chips, bangers & mash. Tucked away but perfectly accessible. Can't beat the legacy and the vibe.

D2Tab_sSlMPHPOAHA30c5Q.text: Service is great here, very cool old spot. Samuel Smiths needs to fix the old brewery bitter up!!! I went to 3 places there was no consistency. I go to London just to have one of the old beers I remembered to be so great, I was so disappointed.

IG5t3TggRvqOfTlRYg9DAQ.text: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese was our first pub stop in London and it delivered as promised.  Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese, rebuilt shortly after the Great Fire of 1666, is one of the oldest pubs in London. There are several famous literary figures associated with the place: Oliver Goldsmith, Mark Twain, Alfred Tennyson, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, and G.K. Chesterton are all said to have been 'regulars'.  Ye Olde Cheshire  is absolutely charming and crammed with tons of history.  The low door entries and tiny steps give you an idea of how short people used to be!  It took us a few moments to locate the dining area. Initially we thought the stand up bar area was the entire pub!  If you walk downstairs, towards the bathrooms, you will see two levels of dining areas.  We lucked out and were able to grab the last table as a group was leaving.  Since our table seated 8-10 we decided to be neighborly and invited another couple to join our table.The atmosphere is very casual.  Order drinks and food at the bar and the bartender will give you a pager while you wait for your food order.  Whoever said English food sucks is absolutely nuts!  Our fish and chips and Shepherd's Pie were awesome!!!  I did skip eating the lackluster peas and carrots on the plates, but overall I was very impressed with our "pub grub"!  The prices for our meals were also very resonable.It was tempting to spend the rest of the night here, but we had other plans in Hampstead and eventually had to leave.  I highly recommend checking out this pub if you are visitng London and want to experience an old fashioned English Pub!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Bar area @ Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Cottage Pie
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Fish and Chips

lVXorLIXMeB471XfRedveg.text: Solid old world pub - definitely a step back in time and worth a visit for everyone. Really great prices too especially for central London. Tip: there is a nominal surcharge on credit/debit cards so bring cash if you want to avoid that.

bEi5X-Klie_rRVnvqZ9aTw.text: One of the oldest pubs in London. It has a list of all the past and present kings and queens of England that have reigned during its time open which is quite an impressive list to say the leastA few mod cons have gone in since it opened with electric lights and plumbing being the major ones! The architecture has remained the same with the low ceilings and doorways so mind your headsThe brick work is fascinating with the arches and the old style wooden stools and table certainly don't take up much space but there isn't much room to swing a cat between the walls. There are a few sections which give it a feeling of space.Not bad food and a standard selection of ales available. I was there with a friend when it was quiet so no idea what the crowd is like at peak timesBy the way it's hidden away down a lane off the Main Street so you need to keep an eye out or you will simply walk straight on byWorth a visit if you are looking for a quirky tourist pub steeped in history, if only the walls could talk in this pub!

IEPko3msFr88lTAw3h49CA.text: Come for the history!Stay for the beer!If you're hungry they can feed you.Tourists and locals alike crowd this place from shortly after opening until closing, it seems, as I've never been here when there wasn't a crowd about.Wonderful beers, and helpful staff, and soak up the vibe along with your beer and before you know it you'll be glad you are here. (nice, that)Cheers!Enjoy!

K3-bD-zGT_j0bfusYWlwlQ.text: Probably in the top 3 bars in the world I have ever walked into.Built for another time, a time before even Dickens (who apparently hated the place), its cavernous, creeky, haunted, and its the London outpost for the Samuel Smith brewery a few miles away.

HjFswwfF2k_PukwRSiSEcg.text: "The Cheese" was recommended by a friend who travels to London for work. The atmosphere is very local and authentic. The small unique rooms make for a cozy feel. We only ordered an appetizer- nachos, which were tasty. The salsa was sweet and completed the dish.  Our room got a bit loud at times, but that should be expected. I met the owner on my way out. He was pleasant and recommend another local pub. Cheers!

zhVC3b6jfEpVCr0i_vaz2w.text: Ate here in the early eighties which might seem like a long time ago until you read that Dickens frequented the place and believe me he was a late-comer. The place was rebuilt a hundred years before there was a Declaration of Independence. Anyway, we tried a couple of the dishes- fish and chips and bangers and mash and found them tasty. Very authentic as the peas really were mushy! Why is that? That afternoon our two-year old was making echoes in Westminster Abbey. A woman with a child on a leash (!) said to us about our daughter "Why don't you pick it up?"  Not in Kansas any more.

t9qXjG8QdzBC64-qLgdCRw.text: Very very cool place. Almost missed it  because it is in a small alley. Good beer, good fish and chips, good people, some history to dig.  Be sure to go all the way down and check out every room on your way. Also look the ground at the beginning of the alley.

-sCfzYewFxJWcA8CgoDZuA.text: Really cool atmosphere as it is very dark and very maze-like in the cellar.if youre a tourist you totally have to check it out once. its actually not as croweded as you think it is, which is an advantage or a disadvantage, however you like it.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. they have a cool variety of beers
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Fruit beers. i recommend the apricot one. it really fits in a beer
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. this meatpie was just delicious!

Z7ba6kAnLhHhq8bSRYRbiQ.text: This place is so cool! I did a walking tour of London with my family and this was on one of our stops. The oldest pub in London! We all enjoyed a nice pint, conversed with a few locals, and then headed on our way. I definitely recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

44xFOCBQwUMFlXYQKScoWQ.text: We had a great time here visiting with friends while in London.  The little side rooms are super cute and perfect if you don't want to sit in the noisier area by the bar.  The fish and chips were tasty, the fish was nicely done.  They also have amazing beers.  My husband loved his chocolate stout and I enjoyed my cherry beer.
