Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate Stout

jVDE5jRg4xK_V0Hr-drBOQ.text: Satisfactory experience !! Good beer, cheerful service, and inimitable ambience. Go.

_XDHTyA0qwVzHTKX_vUNtA.text: Warm and cozy, authentic and delicious -- What I look for in a pub. Went back twice in one week while traveling through London and would go back again.

ggBKUEIuYEa-j9WzlPcRQA.text: Fantastic pub. Apparently one of London's oldest pub. If you manage to get a seat in the little bar just in on the right with the big log fire, you could easily be stay all afternoon watching people coming and going. It is worth going into just to have a look inside. It is however full of tourist doing just that. Not sure if it is somewhere that has many locals. Definitely not somewhere to go with a large crowd.

pLpQ1OXNrN1BAtEoMf3dJw.text: A really good British pub experience - the Sam Smith bitter is worth the trip, and the food doesn't disappoint!

xdPBrSC2Sd3i979K1z5HLw.text: On of our favorite pubs we visited in London when there in July 2015.  We had our best Ale there too.  We had pheasant for dinner and the kids had Burgers and Chips.  So Good!!! One of the oldest pubs in London dating backing to 1600s.  Can be easy to miss since entrance is in a side street but a small sign does hang on Fleet Street marking.  Dickens frequented this pub in his day.

HAKcVKSIhi2NBlUXmL6qBQ.text: Quick glance: + wonderfully atmospheric+ traditional pub grub+ big portion of foodThe pub was rebuilt after the Great Fire of London in 1666 and all I could think while sitting in the cavernous basement was, what would the walls say if the walls could talk? It's great to imagine that this pub has been around when straws probably lined the road, and Lamb Street actually was a marketplace for sheep rather than home to investment firms. Visiting this tucked away pub is great for the imagination. There is an upstairs dining area which you need to book, but downstairs is a fairly roomy and atmospheric basement where you can tuck into a selection of traditional pub grub, washed down with a pint of ale, cider, or stout. The selection of food and drinks may not be extensive as the everyday modern pubs we are accustomed to, but that just adds to the whole experience. The food itself was good and came in large portion, so definitely worth coming back with friends who have never been. And despite its rather touristy status, the food was fairly priced - a main and half a pint was less than a tenner.

---ApoNeg7jrH46vV1hAuw.text: What a terrific pub! Rebuilt, yes rebuilt in1667......oh my! Classic Samuel Smith's on tap and in bottles. Delicious!!

ygBrZymCS6PmOyIfeTewGg.text: Stop in for a pint, have a look, and then head elsewhere for dinner. The building is fantastic, and the history a delight to consider, but the food is horrible.

dReNnOUTm874QXt5NZpS5w.text: Came here for some fish and chips which were really good. Pretty big portion! You can kind of feel the history seeping through the walls. A great stop if you are in the Fleet Street area

LfhKPzXPiugkrcNDziamXw.text: I am really not fond of this pub  it's dark and dingy with quite low ceilings and narrow corridors. I know it's an old building, but for me I still feel it lacks character.I've also always found it hard to find a place to sit. However I have only been with large groups and at night.This is a Sam Smith's pub so it's very cheap, but then I don't really like the taste of Sam Smith's products.Don't get me wrong, I think if I wanted to get drunk for cheap this might be the place to go, or maybe in the day it is quieter, but for me whilst I usually really like pubs with history, this just feels a bit gimmicky.I have not tried the food so cannot comment on this.

tlG8ATZgVnwlDocBMU8ksw.text: Dissapointed. Some beers were unavailble because manager wasn't there to replace kegs. Poor selection of healthy food.

iwWhESCE0YobqHJlviuG5A.text: Supposedly the "oldest bar in London"... so we had to check it out. Again, I'm not a "pub" kind of girl, so I probably didn't appreciate this as much as the next girl, but I was fascinated with the dark, almost "shrunken" decor! I mean i'm not what you would consider tall, but seriously you have to watch your head everywhere you go because the ceilings are so low and the hallways are so narrow!! We went all the way down to the basement. I had some sort of "pot pie" with meat and mushrooms. it came with fries and it was good. I'd suggest this place, if for no other reason, then the novelty of saying you went to the OLDEST pub in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Bar downstairs

Wh1eNDOXqWNq89P5SvdMFg.text: I'm fond of this place. I like the small removed entrance, and the old, dark interior. I like the good value Sam Smith's brand drinks. I like the sawdust spread over the floor.The pub is very old, and you get that impression from the coolness and calmess of the inside. It makes me feel like I'm curled up in a Dickens novel. This has the overall effect of giving the place a dim and sleepy feel, although it can get rather busy after 5pm.The smoking area is slightly removed from the entrance and doesn't really fit the feel of the venue, but it's still better than most 'stand on the street' options available at other pubs on Fleet Street.In general, as I've already mentioned.. I'm fond of this place.

HYkIfAPbBUIUIiqKZZ2Oig.text: Oh, I am an asshole for having never reviewed this place. When you first arrive, you expect it to be overly touristy. It is. But strangely, magically, it doesn't even matter. This place still rocks. It doesn't try to sell you t-shirts despite being a historic and popular pub (can you tell I'm American?). Prices are more than reasonable since they serve Sam Smith's. Awesome photo ops for the ladies under the entryway to the formerly men's only bar right inside the entrance. If you're a lit fan, you'll have heard about Dickens referencing this place, and other legends slinking around. I am never sad to be here. Ever. It's a great place and there's plenty of seating, even if you have to wait a short amount of time for a table.

-P4kl_8bPXxHaLFLCUOyKw.text: Overall, I'm a fan of this quaint bar. It has an amazing backstory, and minus the low ceilings on the stairwells. I had a great time. It can get a little warm, but that's not a real issue. The staff was polite, friendly, and helped us pick the perfect beers for our evening. The only downside is the fact it closes early on the weekends. Aside from that, we had a great time exploring and taking in the history!

t6jtiRThK-WtmRWF-UhhTg.text: This was definetely an adventure.  The stairs spiral down out of control into the bottom floor where it looked like a scene from inglorious basterds.  The staff friendly and welcoming.  We ordered our libations, then headed up what seemed an endless twisting and turning of stairs and hallways where we arrived in the top to be seated at a long table.  Our waiter was friendly and inviting laughing with us as we rambled on in drunken slurrs.  The London steak was no compare to Texas, but it wasn;t bad either, and the price was right for being downtown.  It was cooked to perfection!!  The peppercorn gravy was delicious.  Lots of fun, a must for the casual tourist.

TIlHVwPb81wXRpqma82jnQ.text: I'm sure I'd already written a review of this place already, but I guess not.I used to really like this pub with all its different sections and nooks. In fact, I still do like the place, but the novelty has worn off slightly. It is still a nice place to come and drink, especially in the winter when coming in from the cold streets somehow accentuates the warmth and cosiness of the venue. I like the innovative solution they have found to serving food in a pub with so many hidey holes. They give you a beeper, so that you know when to come and pick up your meal. Of course everyone prefers their food brought to them, but that would be tricky here.So for drinks there is the usual cheap Sam Smith's selection, which I like as a change, but get a bit bored of if I visit their pubs too regularly. I don't go that often recently anyway...especially since I learned what jerks they are - oldham-chronicle.co.uk/n….The vaulted cellars may date back to the 13th Century, the rest of the pub was rebuilt after the great fire of London reduced it to fondue. It also has its fair share of famous patrons if you care to look it up.

ZRWiaoNN-KJLaISnlOamcg.text: I consider this a must stop for anyone visiting London or England for the first time. You just don't get the opportunity to see a place like this back in the USA where the place has about 1,000 violations of the fire code, ADA, and on and on - which is awesome. At 6'1 you are ducking to not hit your head many places, there are so many little tucked aways rooms and seating areas, and the place smells like wood burning stove from 400 years ago! You really can feel what it must have been like in generations past to sit there, and the best part is there are no TV's and no loud music - just friends and family enjoying a pint and pub food!

DEOxj5GqH1ZOM9ww3DxoUQ.text: Service was pretty good, but I'd say that was the best thing about this place along with the design. It is cool to eat in a table that you know could've been seating Charles Dickens back in the day. It is a little hidden and you must go behind an alley to find it. The food was okay, I think people are overrating the fish 'n chips because they honestly weren't that great. The chips are served warm and were the best part but the fish is scaley and don't even bother asking for tartar sauce. It came with no sauce and I see why. I ordered some tartar sauce to go with and it tasted like old mayonnaise so don't bother. They do have many different unique and organic drinks though which I heard they are pretty good. Don't bother ordering them if you aren't 18 though, this place is strict.

5AS95y5ryramXXoEu6zcAg.text: This pub oozes with character and history. There are at least 5 distinct seating areas,  each with their own vibe, although not all of the areas are open all the time. Sam Smith beers and ciders are your only option, although they have some great selections. Keep in mind that the beers listed on the print menus are for all Sam Smith pubs, and the selection at each particular pub will vary. Prices here are very fair, and the food is good, although not the best pub food I've come across. It's an order at the bar kind of place, which is fine by me.

aUEiwTZc0oZnPoHtT04CpQ.text: I had a good time here. We came in from the heat and went 3 floors down to an almost crypt-like bar. They say the place hasn't changed since Dickens was there and I think I believe it! I'll admit if it wasn't famous for being a favorite of Charles Dickens, I would not have found this and that would have been a shame.Great place and it was nice and cool.The prices were fair and the portions were good.  Yes, I had to try the Steak and Ale pie since it IS on Fleet Street and all...

CfjRioaS3jUkVED61sqJFw.text: After reading about this pub in one of JK Rowling's books, i had really wanted to come check it out. The opportunity came when my friends from Toronto came to visit and we wanted to take them to a traditional English pub where people stand around and order drinks and food directly at the bar. This place was more than we bargained for. Not only are there more than rooms of bars, there are also two dining rooms so it got a bit confusing.As soon as you walk in, there's a small standing bar in one room, then a dining room on the other side. Keep walking past the stairs, another room with a big bar and plenty of seating. Down the stairs, there are two half levels with short cave-like ceilings for dining, and one more floor down is a giant room with a big bar and picnic tables. We did not venture to the upper floors.Food-wise, it was alright. My boyfriend had a steak and ale pie that was absolutely delicious, while my fish and chip was plain. No tartar sauce available so you gotta stick with the vinegar (or mustard if you like it that way). The Chicken pie was decent, but nothing mind-blowing.If you are just there to check out a really old pub in london where a lot of old famous Londoners used to hang, this is a great place for you to grab a pint - the only issue might be that every bar in this pub might have a slightly different selection of booze (they have a relatively wide selection).

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Fish and chips
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Steak and ale pie

h9WKsnGn2Yu4oLvgZQr69w.text: Wanted something very "British" for our last meal in London and came across the Olde Cheshire Cheese. We walked in right as the restaurant portion of the place opened up and were able to get a seat for 2.Started with a cheese tart (yummy!) and had the steak and kidney pie for the main. It was ok, but definitely for the adventurous if you're not used to eating kidney.Had an orange chocolate mousse to finish and it was DECADENT. Thick rich chocolate mousse took some time to finish.  Overall, great meal in great atmosphere. The waitress was a doll despite being the only staff in the restaurant.

DURwIzrkEk4pWCb8QeEcTg.text: This pub is full of twists and turns and has a fantastic ambiance. My husband and I came in after a friend recommended it on our first night in London and really enjoyed it. Beers were affordable and the Ploughmans Board we nibbled on was delicious. This is a great spot to see one of the areas oldest pubs.

zLB1xjmuX-mPJxUM84EHAw.text: What an awesome pub.  A true history where likes of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Benjamin Franklin were regulars. It was burned down and rebuilt since 1667. The entrance is in a small little alley way with a tiny door. But once inside you have several different room, bars and floors which go underground. Old wood bar counters, alot of wood and bricks, low ceilings where at times it has a sign to watch your head, tiny clean toilets. Such a cozy place. Little coat racks around to hang your coat. Quite a few beers on tap and by the bottle. They seem to have some wine and a couple of hard liquors but not mixed cocktails. Some of the different bars served different drinks. We also ate here which was great for bar food. Got the fish and chips, the fish was tender, outside flaky & not too fishy. Plenty of fries and side of mashed peas. Really great prices all around. The bartenders are nice. No table service you order at the bar.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. It was almost like a bar for little people
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

iui6bnpXr4kneUT0uft6CA.text: Please, please don't go here. Or if you go, just do a quick tour and head out. It is totally not worth the hype. We went here for lunch and walked out after having ordered our food and beer. First, they have a weird system where you order the food in the basement and when the buzzer buzzes, you have to carry it to your table, even if you're seated on the upper levels. Second, the food is just horrible. The fish and chips I ordered was sad. A big filet fried in thick tasteless batter. My wife's mushroom stroganoff was equally tasteless with nothing other than cream and lukewarm, dried up rice to go with. The food overall was almost cold by the time we got it. The beer is also a disappointment. The bartenders are quiet, don't really engage with you and you just don't feel like you're in a pub. Hardly any locals here either. Overall I'll say the place has a nice dungeony feel to it but nothing else about it stands out.

AUhiQDFysFo651RHtd0g7A.text: This is a fun spot because of the history but is overwhelmed with tourists.  Our party of 4 stopped for a late lunch, barely found a table in the basement, and were told we couldn't order food for at least 30 minutes because the kitchen was backed up.  Drinks were on our own and had to be fetched from the bar on the main level.  I had been there before and with a party of two on a weekday it was okay, but it wasn't able to stand up to holiday crowds.

YUh0oax-YsRhoTx8f4XkWQ.text: I give it 4 stars- 5 for historical value and atmospheric value and 3 for the actual food. If you've never dined in a 300+ year old pub while in London, you're doing it wrong.The house made cola was great! The roast beef sandwich was tasty and the sausages and mash were good too, just nothing really special. Just to sit in this place made for a good experience.

JIswVGyuP-OHqqK_gnoV-g.text: The basement service at the bar wasn't that great, the bartender forgot one of our orders and we had to go back to ask about it. We came on a rainy day and while walking up from the basement pass the restrooms, there was a strong smell of urine. I don't know how the people drinking on that level can stand it. The upper level bartender was much better and served us up right. I will come back, just not downstairs.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

Tn2w6ODDoAyKwyg4Y80kkQ.text: One of my favorite pubs in London.    A lot of pubs claim ancient provenance, and some of them are  even seem plausibly Victorian---but Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is plausibly ancient.   Of course, the original bar burned down in 1666 (this isnt all that far from the monument), but this bar has had many famous drinkers, from Samuel Johnson to Benjamin Franklin.   It's kind of a tourist trap, but there are so many small alcoves you can get away from the crowd.   The food is good---by pub standards .  I think the room upstairs has a chophouse with a different menu.

fn4g7vNLMkkUwLYRsEDAlw.text: Loved visiting this 400+ year old pub (rebuilt in 1666) in the heart of London. Friendly service and great Samuel Smith's beer (get the stout). But the real selling point is having a pint in this ancient room, you can feel the history...it's a sacred place for beer lovers!

ql2vd6n5tdXakw_FERJ76Q.text: Oh, how I loved this place!Everything you want from a cozy, historic pub: Tiny staircases, small tables, low ceilings, original features and great drinks! We were in a hurry, and only stayed for one drink. We also didn't have food. But, I could see myself staying here for hours, and making it a regular fixture in my weekend routine.  A major plus: The bathrooms had been fully renovated, so you could enjoy the historic charm with the added benefit of a swanky toilet.

KT-irc5heNkqTLSMDeKBVg.text: This curious pub has lunch served two flights down in a basement.  It feels really old.  The fish and chips involves a real fish, rather than a filet.  It was super yummy.  Great selection of Samuel Smith ale.  Price for fish and chips was L 12.50 and service seemed to be added into the check, so lunch for two with two pints was about 32 pounds.  Not cheap.  Good though.  Particularly if you like eating in a basement.

18FmDsGbAzV5WIRycvHLcA.text: Cool "cave" sitting area when you go down. Sat and read abook with a pint. Definitely what you think of when visiting an old city like London.

Ab7O5mRrTG_MKS__kkZ1Fg.text: It is with a heavy heart that I have to give Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese a 3 star rating. This pub has been one of my favourites in London for the last 2 years however until this week I had never eaten in their restaurant or spent longer than an hour or so in there - sadly this week I did just that and the service really let the pub down.We were seated in the restaurant and straight away the problems started. We had to ask to be given the menus, we had to ask to order drinks, we even had to ask to have our order taken (twice) and this continued throughout the evening with further drinks, desserts, the bill etc etc. I realise it was Christmas and they were busy but I do think that if we didn't continue to ask we would have been sat there for hours on end and never received anything.Now for the food. I was VERY excited to see that steak and kidney pudding was on the menu (it's the northern in me) but when I went to order it the waitress informed me that they'd run out. I really felt like we should have been notified of this before hand as we then had to take a further 5 minutes to decide what we wanted and amend our orders. So, I eventually opted for the roast beef. The beef was cooked well and the gravy flavoursome however there definitely wasn't enough of it and you had to order additional vegetables and gravy if needed (which we felt was needed). Overall it was a slightly disappointing evening but what I will say is that this hasn't put me off Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese, it was just a bit of a let down. I will definitely head back when it's quieter and give the pudding a try.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Samuel Johnson (the man to write the first dictionary). We were sat at his favourite table :)
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. The menu!
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Sausage and mash - recommended!

re5J_niKZCIjJ5_gGPwgqQ.text: This pub is not on London's top tourist attractions list, but it might as well be. Every time I have a guest over from the other side of the pond, I conclude my Fleet Street tour with a sojourn up and down the many stairways and levels of this fabulous pub. The best part? It's older than at least a few dozen countries, mine being one of them!Walking into Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese feels like walking into a hobbit's house in the best possible sense. Turn down a Dickensian alleyway to enter the wooden panelled interior, with dim lighting and curved ceilings that make you feel as if it was carved into a hollowed-out tree. The tight entryways and cavernous bottom floor give this pub even more character. The good beer selection and its prized location means it's almost always packed. However, it is surprisingly expansive so you can usually find a place among its many drinking areas.  Absolutely a must visit for every true Londoner. I am definitely a devoted fan. The fact that it is literally a three minute walk from work (doesn't) helps!

0IVaoa2Z3KYbHr-iZQqg1g.text: The hubby and I are visiting London for a couple days and found this place through yelp and I'm glad we trekked all the way here for a drink. Less than a 10 min walk from the Blackfriars stop, located in an alleyway with a big round sign stating its presence. The top floor is for proper meals like steak and the such while the bottom two floors are designated more for drinking and bar food. We opted for the latter so we made our way down the creaky staircase into a room that looked like a wine cellar with little alcoves that held about 6 small tables in total which led to a bigger room with cafeteria style seating where the bar was located. Cool old pub vibe, it felt like I was being transported back in time. According to the hubby, the beer is on point and damn cheap at about £2 a pint. Can't beat that in the U.S. even after the exchange rate. I tried the alpine lager and I usually can't handle much beer bc it makes me feel bloated but it was surprisingly refreshing and light. Food is ok, tried the chicken & mushroom pie and bangers and mash. Expect your typical bar food - decent/edible but by no means worth trekking out here for. Would definitely visit again for the beer and old school pub vibe if I had the chance

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Chicken & mushroom pie
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Bottom floor where the bar is located
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Entrance to the lower level seating

lsGcuOqERenTCk0pUJKBtA.text: A historical gem hidden in an alley way on Fleet Street. I was staying in a flat in the 'Queen of Scots Building' next door and knew I had to try this place out. We actually ate here twice on our 7 day stay in London. The Bangers and Mash with onion gravy is amazing. Great cider on tap too. You cant find cider like that in the states. The pub is a dark multi-level labrynth. The chop house in the ground floor. I never went to the upper levels, but down below are 3 split levels with more dining space and a bar in the cellar. The cool cellar was welcoming on a hot day in June (it was in the 90's Fahrenheit and humid when we were there!). The cellar had large bench tables perfect for bug groups. I also had their fish n chips, which was good, but the bangers are my go-to dish. Prices are reasonable. A pint is pretty cheap and dishes go for around 10£. The loo was surprisingly modern in this 400 year old pub. Charles Dickens was a regular here and has a favorite table in the chop house. A great way to experience a very traditional British pub.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Get it.
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

wsY3v0HaLyMj4QN_F7E_AQ.text: Great atmosphere..food was lacking.  I got the fish and chips and thought this place would get it right..they didnt.

gDVlswsYAcEmnScsGcY6uQ.text: Five for the pub, three for the food. This pub is awesome. It's not too far from downtown and it is the perfect old, classic, traditional pub. You walk in and its almost like a maze - it has small adjoining rooms where you can sit, eat or drink. Its really fun - but always watch your head! They had a good selection on draft and in bottles. Well rounded menu and kind staff. We got the fish & chips with mushy peas. Unfortunately it wasn't very good - probably a 2 star. I like my fish without skin on, this came with skin on, which caused the breading to not really attach. The chips were little cold/soggy and the mushy peas were so bland. Come for a drink at this traditional pub but go for food somewhere else

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

ykhrB5bPlWYb0LZlHhOHeg.text: This is one of the oldest and most historic pubs in London; well, it's really more of a complex than one pub. There are several floors but the basement is the neatest, as long as you're not claustrophobic. In the basement, you'll see pics of how the bar used to look back in the day which is pretty cool as you compare the area you're sitting in with the pic.I think it's super cool the notion that this has been around since the Great Fire and people still flock here after work to get a pint or two and try the meat pies. We are, after all, on Fleet Street (Yes, I really like Sweeney Todd). The food is actually pretty good (I LOVED the mushroom beef pie) and of course they have chips galore which goes splendidly with all the beer they have on tap.Be forewarned, the place is standing room and elbow room only. We happened to snag a table and some grateful locals shared it with us. Others, who were sitting or standing on steps that rainy day, weren't as fortunate.This pub is just NEATO and AWESOME AND AUTHENTIC, and why you go to London pubs in the first place.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Meat pie is a MUST on Fleet Street!

9tl9BctAcjYaqeEKzni2cQ.text: This place is brilliant. The ales are very good and the atmosphere is very friendly. It gets crowded, but what good pub doesn't?! I agree with the other reviewers, it's well worth a visit and then another and another! By the way, I like the photo that a fellow Qyper took for this establishment- I took one and it wasn't nearly that good! :D

uQiAjlAvDfm_7FZDcH5HOg.text: What a great place and so much history.  An old friend recommended this place and told us that Charlies Dickens use to drink here!If an out of towner (like me), it's definitely a tough place to find.  Its like located in a narrow alleyway with a little old sign hanging above it.You first walk in and thing, wow...this is hidden and small but if you explore further, you'll find a narrow, low ceiling, hidden stair case towards the middle-back of the place.You walk down the stairs and there are several floors of cavernous drinking space.  You would have never thought that at first.  You hit the bottom floor (I think like three levels down) and its like the biggest room with another bar and serving delicious food!Overall, this place is awesome and its WAY older than any bar in NYC (yes, even McSorelys).  Definitely have to check it out.

-0t4rLMWNPPuxfP-naPD0Q.text: I've been here several times since my last review and have changed my mind regarding my rating.  The first time I went I did not have access to the bottom floor of the pub which has great atmosphere, and I've also been to a function in one of the upper rooms which had a lot of character.  The food is not so overpriced when you're ordering from the pub menu rather than the dining room menu.  Nothing special, but decent pub food and a fun, historic-albeit-a-bit-touristy (it is Fleet St, after all) atmosphere.  I've been here for just drinks, too, which is always fun.  Lots of great brews.

vRDdGYyXptYZiB_3r2XhgQ.text: Fish and chips - the traditional British thing - not really nicely preprared here. I read all these reviews saying fish and chips are great, but I did not like my dish. Sorry, I do not think I am coming back again.

ZgusyYjiCovGyjw5NruROQ.text: Out on a Saturday evening's pub-skylarking with a friend we found ourselves in Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese, and I have to say - I was very impressed! Initially the heat from the fireplace seemed oppressive, but that was possibly in contrast from the frigid chill we'd come in from. As our eyes adjusted to the stygian darkness of the front bar we managed to find a couple of chairs and thought "Ah well, this is a tourist pub - we'll just grab one and then be on our way". 2 hours later we were still there, having shifted to pints of ale with port chasers & chatting to a few punters who'd rocked up - we met a couple of lawyers from Lancashire, and a couple of tourists who had romanced across 4 continents. Maybe it was the fact that the pub - erected in 1667 - claims to have played host to a couple of hundred years' worth of literati, such as Dickens, Twain, Voltaire, and Dr Johnson, and so visitors entered eager for it to present a memorable trip and experience, rather than just another nice old building to stand in, look at, and walk out of again. As we sat, sipped & extemporised more than one new group of tourists ingressed - typically a shivering & slightly dejected looking gaggle led by an excited young man in front clutching a guidebook: and all of whom warmed up nicely, put away at least a swift half, before returning to the arctic Fleet-Streetian wastelands. I can't comment on the quality of food, as we only supped of the hop & vine. The pristineness of the toilets was remarkable - we suspected a recent renovation, but in contrast to the ancient smoke-stained walls upstairs, the loos were almost hospital-like! Having read other reviews here complaining about short pints & whatnot - the "standard" beers are dirt cheap (as Sam Smith's pubs always are), so getting 1/4 of an inch more head on your pint than you'd like isn't the end of the world... either let them know the tide's out, or quit whining. Realistically, the joy in this pub's in sitting back soaking up the atmosphere & ambience and enjoying a snug fireside chat - so get to it! It's a treasure. The only regret I've got is that the darkness in there was so impenetrable that I wasn't able to get a decent photo of the front room. And it had nothing to do with all the beer I'd drunk, honest.

wDjwfSuxNxfjQx1wbQfmHQ.text: Popped in here for lunch after a nearby meeting. I had heard of it, as the oldest or one of the oldest pubs in London (perhaps even the UK) but since I no longer live in the UK and a decent pub is one thing I really miss, this looked like a great place to try out. So the inside is dark and dingy, small rooms partitioned off, with steep creaky stairs leading to each floor. We sat upstairs on a table and I had a MASSIVE steak and kidney pudding with a pint of Bitter ('we only have the one, Sir') It was lovely but I wasn't hungry for two days afterwards!! Service was OK  seemed like there wasn't enough staff for the numbers of diners but not too bad.

cAP5gX5wKuAuUbPyYuc6nA.text: I had researched some traditional pubs to try when I had first arrived in London because I wanted to try traditional British food. This was one of the places I came across and so a group of us decided to venture out and give it a try. It was a little bit hard to find but it is a little bit of a hidden gem. There are sort of two floor which sort of threw us off guard. There is a top floor which is a little more upscale. Then, you venture down several windey staircases into a lower basement which is a dim lit area. It gives off a very old school vibe and you definitely feel like you are in a pub many years ago. I ordered some sort of pie that had mushrooms in it along with a snakebite to drink. I know some of the people I was with ordered the fish & chips but I can't remember any of the other entrees. My pie was quite good and I remember my friend saying his fish and chips was good as well.This place has a very nice little ambiance to it. It is definitely not fancy by any means but if you are looking for a traditional pub this is an awesome place that really gives you that old school pub vibe with some great food and drink as well!!

fZNI34c0m5ZJh7sf1TvsxQ.text: I can travel across the world and still find someone from the same city as me. Being an American is really annoying. I came to this place and managed to run into two guys from San Francisco, and we discussed our local coffee, weather, and they liked baseball, so not much else. Oh, and I also explained to one of them that "pickle" in England does not mean dill. A pickle is a different food entirely. We drank and mused that it is particularly odd to be sat in a building that is older than every Western-influenced thing in your entire country. Strange.Ah, but this is a Sam Smith pub. We can pick up some of the Samuel Smith brews back here in Crapland, but they don't export their organic fruit beers. Samuel Smith's Organic Cherry Beer is my favourite beer of all time. Screw every other beer, this one tastes like cherry soda and I love it. Downstairs in the cellar was about the only place my very tall friend could sit without hitting his head (constant reminders to mind his head never help), but down there on a weeknight we got attentive bar service and were able to eat our fish and chip baskets in comfort. I can't tell you how many times I went back up to the bar and plunked down a £2 coin for that Cherry Beer, but I do remember hugging an electric car later, so I'd say I had enough.

9G--DWutp8fhwjnpBUQicQ.text: So it's a bit of a tourist standard, but imagine my pleasant surprise one Saturday while schlepping my parents through the City's sights, to find the luncheon room open and beckoning with seats and solid 'auld English pub fare' that didn't make me choke!!!  With my mother enthroned in Sam Johnson's corner (the resemblance to his portrait above was a bit eerie...) and my pops in Charles Dickens' old seat, the coal fire in the grate gave just enough heat and smoke to make me mistake the place for a pretty authentic and well run reenactment joint.  Of course the Aussie accent on the super friendly service put the lie to that, but lo it's a real-life, runnin' pub!!!So, have some out-of-towners visiting? Get there around 12:00-12:30 (lunch is done by 14:30), order up some lamb shank, scotch roast beef, steak & kidney pudding and bubble & squeak, and settle back with an indy ale safe in the knowledge you've outdone your tour-guide duties, with the least amount of pain.

_5km_jo5vs6m_AEzaUXL9A.text: Great old pub on Fleet Street. Lots of History. Often crowded. Cheap pints. No branded booze. Mind your head on the stairs.It's also quite near the Templar Church if you're into that whole Crusader military order thing.

Mvhz-14tw9299XfSa7zQXQ.text: A 1667 rebuilt pub was the draw for us to come here.  It is nothing spectacular.  The beer was the same as everywhere else and the food was mediocre.  My entire party ordered the fish and chips and was so disappointed with the tasteless dish.  This pub warrant just a 1/2 pint if you want to do a pub crawl in London.  The downstair bar in the wine cellar was really cool.

jBjphAS8oUkTMZzyl-ccAw.text: Great Sam Smiths pub. Not sure I'd want to be in there during peak times but it's a great old building and I found the beers cheap (Sam Smiths pubs stock all their own brand drinks and are usually cheaper than other pubs). The toilets are totally modern. Check out the writing in the old books on the way to the loos upstairs too. Can someone tell me what the double-decker tables are for? Empties? Candles? What?Oh, we had nibbles in here. The mushroom soup was very warming on a snowy winter afternoon and the fried cheese tasty. Not sure about sit down meals here, we were only stopping in for a couple.

sYSWgNMQuOcbs1XEsIsONQ.text: this is my third favorite pub in all of london and a great place to take my friends when they come to visit the uk. the historical aspect was what first got me to come around a few years back and i loved it ever since. the maze like hallways and various little rooms are anything but off-putting. the atmosphere is really relaxed and very much open for anyone. love the house cider and ale, which are definitely worth a try

hpWrAdmIbnPUFklol2vnFg.text: I really really want to give this place five stars. It's a lovely pub while great little cubby holes and nooks and crannies (although does it have more nooks than it's sister pub The Princess Louise? Probably not). It's a Sam Smiths pub so you'd expect the rounds to be cheap, right? Nope. Not if you order anything other than the draught beer. I was feeling hungover so ordered a cheery beer and a soda water. The bill was £5.10. EXCUSE ME? £5.10?! Apparently charging £1.20 for soda water is normal. Their tap water is free - so they've just charged me over a pound for bubbles. But they'd already poured it and I had to pay for it. Not impressed. £4 for cherry beer means that it's not a cheap drink - you only get a bottle. My cheap (hungover) night out was somewhat marred by this. But dammit the cherry beer is really yummy. But if you're looking for a cheap night out, best stick to the draught beer. Had I done that, this place would have got five stars.

_DUz-LiMGvE0MGDAxRo8lA.text: First time visiting London and was expecting some great pub experiences. Although we had plenty, sadly, this was not one. Brews are the same as you get at any of the pubs in London. Atmosphere was for sure "old world". You come into the main bar and if you want something to eat, you wind your way down stairs to the three rooms where they serve food. Ofcourse, no one from the establishment tells you this, you have to ask the patrons. They don't have wait staff, and don't bus tables. When we got there we found a table free so we waited for someone to come by a clean it. After ten minutes, I couldn't find anyone and a lady nearby told us to pile the dishes aside and order at the bar in the next floor down. We did, and got fish and chips and the meat pie. Both were really lacking in everything. I don't understand why in England the chips are not crisp, and the peas are mushy but, this was the same just about every single place we went to. I would say that if you want a pint and maybe a n appetizer in a really old pub, this is the one. If you want to go for a meal, go somewhere else.

vXmh9fldNusTFXXQKA8ZBg.text: I HAD to make my way down to this pub, mainly because of the location and the fact that it is the oldest pub in London.  I had to see if it was worth the trek.  And it WAS!  While it wasn't all that crowded (which I was grateful for) I did wish there were a couple of more bartenders, and/or waitstaff.  But the food was great (for England, that is...HA!) and the prices were reasonable

tF2qJtMWfpP73_gJLcc28A.text: This is a real quaint olde world style pub on fleet street. It was a damp saturday night in the heart of the city and it was still busy so its obviously quite a pull. The tourists ove it because its untouched and genuine. Made up of lots of tiny crocked rooms over 4 or 5 floors its very cosy with warm roaring fires in a couple of the rooms.the prices are very reasonable maybe the cheapest place to drik in central london. The low star rating is simply because the choice of drinks is so limited. However for a quirky visit its well worth it.

rhCi-6R4seJky6B9H2FqQg.text: This pub oozes character. And I will admit, I had walked past the alley entranceway about 20 times before realizing (through Yelp) that it's actually a pub. Inside, the place is classic: wood everywhere, lots of different seating options, staircases, big rooms, little rooms, dining rooms. For ambience this place gets five stars, no question. On the night I visited (Friday, 8pm) the place was full but not crowded. There was only one bartender preparing drinks, though, and I think there should have been two. Not a huge deal, but we did have to wait about seven minutes for a beer. And as far as drink selection goes, this pub is about average. I do like Sam Smith, so as far as tied houses go, I would rank Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese above, say, a Youngs or a Fullers house. But compared against a free house with decent selection, Ye Olde earns runner-up status. Although, to Mr. Smith's credit, he does charge bargain prices for his pints; there's almost nowhere in this city where you can find a pint for £1.99.So to sum, Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is a good pub with that old-world, historical vibe. For the discerning beer drinker the beer selection is average, but for the average drinker (or tourist, or cost-conscious dude) the Sam Smith range will meet their needs. I would bring a guest here and will probably return at some point as the pub is about one block from my lady's place of work. Overall a nice pub that everyone in London should check out at least once.

_uoK7XKECF9S5NqRh210ug.text: As a Yank, this was my first visit.  As I like to search out the oldest pubs when in European cities, this made the google cut.   The location and appearance certainly lends to the authenticity.  Upon entering there was a warm fire and the wood of centuries gone by.  We grabbed a couple pints of Smiths and headed downwards into the earth.  Mind your heads going down.  Apparently Englishmen were much shorter in the 17th century.  It is cozy and intimate with small rooms.  You can feel the history as you sit there.  No food for us, but well worth a stop for a pint or two.  We'll be back next time we're through London.

_fhKEbirxATNDTy0CO3i1A.text: if I had to sum up this place in one word it would be BRILLIANTthe number of nights I've spent in this pub drinking decent beers & wine with my mates!atmosphere is greatstaff are fantasticthey even do great food! (only gripe is that their kitchen closes a tad too early)great location close enough for me to stagger homewarm and welcoming pub

_8NT16NtZm9RuX9iLDxWzg.text: I really enjoy going to places with a bit of history and this place did not disappoint.  It has been around since the 1600s.  We mostly sat in the upstairs pub by the entrance.  It was small with a couple of tables but it had a nice historical feel.  Came here and had a few pints after exploring the city.  This is a great place to stop by to have a pint and rest if you are a tourist and need a little place to stop and rest while walking up and down fleet street.

HQV6jdpIwkfx0JyBCheFCQ.text: Not a fan.  Will never go back.  The 2 stars come due to the fact that the location and atmosphere of the place is super cool.  Maybe if you just want to drink beer this is a great spot.  I had fish and chips, and it was a terrible experience.  Some people may have had better than me, but my wife and I disliked it thoroughly.  I had fish and chips one other time while in London, and loved it.  I cannot say the same about my experience here.

71MbQtIIqRYzyZoEld9s6w.text: My wife, who is Texan, was awed by the fact of it being rebuilt in 1667 just after the great fire. About 65 years before George Washington was a twinkle in his father's eye. The atmosphere was welcoming with friendly staff and happy diners. The menu was festooned with potentially repugnant old English delights for me along with the less adventurous traditional roast meats and puddings for my wife and our 9 year old daughter. We were a little concerned at first as the wine list consisted of Red or White but our fears were unfounded as the red turned out to be very good indeed. The food was good honest unpretentious English grub. My wife enjoying the roast beef, Yorkshire puddings with trimmings, which was well prepared and the meat nicely rare, My daughter had some of the best bangers and roast potatoes, they mercifully allow substitutions, I have ever tasted and I had the steak & kidney pudding although neither of them wanted to try mine for some unknown reason. My steak & kidney pud was indeed traditional. It had a mildly worrying ripe flavor and it contained more kidney than steak which was crowned with a thick stodgy suet crust (absolutely delicious). The presentation of the meals would have sent Gordon Ramsay into apoplexy but this went well with the surroundings & I don't think Charles Dickens would have complained. My bum started to hurt about thirty minutes into the meal as the benches are hardwood. However I think this may be a Dickensian way of getting the diners to finish their food quickly & move along. In the spirit of the place I endured this discomfort as I am sure these benches have been shined by more auspicious bums than my own. We went for a couple of the English puddings and tried the Welsh rarebit out of curiosity all of which were reminiscent of school dinners. The sticky toffee pudding was great but I would advise you to give the bread & butter pudding and anything with custard a miss as it was watery & tasteless. Good fun, interesting and cheap food, nice staff, bring a cushion.

sQWWF-zq7KiFgVEw9encNQ.text: Tricky tricky... to find, and apparently to pronounce while giving directions. Say it five times fast, go on... But you know how I love finding places off of main roads in dark alleyways, so Cheshire Cheese and I are bound to be meeting again in the near future.  We stopped in after being around St Paul for a bit, and I was skeptical that there was going to be anything worth stopping at off of Fleet st at night, it all kind of seemed to die out after 8 or 9. The beers were great, and the abundance of rooms gives you the space to pick a spot without being jammed in somewhere...and the prices were all pretty cheap.  It's going to be added to my list of must-stop pub hops!

S-hJ4jFb5hfkqwODmHqBZg.text: Yes it's touristy, but what would you expect from the oldest pub in London? It's still got plenty of character and the multitude of levels and rooms makes it quite easy to escape the wankers.And the beer (Sam Smith's) is only £1.99/pint.  You really can't do much better than that.

dKmVMy1NMBI4GSq3r0O4Jg.text: THE oldest pub in London - it's definitely a hole in the wall since the entrance is via an alleyway! It's very dark inside but it makes you feel like there's been a lot of history and deals being dealt here. The pub is pretty small but the beer is really cheap. Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area, if not for beer, than for the history of this place!

81wSXTjyBc3iMeJYWdiIkA.text: A true pub where you can dine and drink amidst the dark wood and tight corners, knowing that such famous literary figures as Dickens, Tennyson, and Twain once spent their hours here. It has a truly old and historic feel while offering delicious, real English food (it wasn't until I ate here that I could say I'd had real English food). I had the steak and then an apple crumble - both were amazing comfort food.I would definitely go here again, making sure to take any new comers to the city here as a site-seeing stop as well.

GiniizfqMyHD7eZWCf2jkA.text: this bar has it all! HISTORY- but i don't know what it is. SPACE- because no one can find it. CHEAP DRINKS- and i'm broke so i need it. STICKY TOFFEE PUDDING- because everyone loves a good pud pud!the bar made for a perfect post-graduation celebration location. as we all gathered centrally walking up fleet street looking for a new place to go. I had heard of the cheshire cheese before and had always been curious about seeing it. and i am so glad that I did, it was my lil treasure chest of pubs. I have a feeling that it's not always as empty as it was on that fatefully freezing thursday, so I know I was lucky to have such a good introduction.lets go back there again. now. and lets be sure to get a table again... maybe this time we can get one by the fireplace, and lets open up those strange/empty decorative boxes on the wall.

-5iKWUMlzitL_AFR8tm93A.text: I'm really torn on this place, and I see the good and the bad, but I know that I would never ever suggest going here, and wouldn't go back unless there's no way around it.In my positive review, I'd say:An absolutely interesting pub to bring friends or visitors to because it feels like a historic maze, and you can almost imagine dice games being played among whores and returning soldiers in 1724.  There are multiple rooms and nooks and crannies over three stories and a courtyard.  The food is cheap and not terrible, and the drinks are decently priced.  Mostly this place is worth it for the history and the story.In my negative review, I'd say: If you have any issues with claustrophobia or any inclination toward cleanliness at all, skip this place.  It is always SO PACKED in the evenings that you can't move from one room to another, have to fight to get the to bar, and have to wait ages to get up or down any stair case.  It's a terrible place for meeting friends because you will never find them, and there's no cell signal in half of the place.  The bathrooms are pretty gross, and the temperature control is atrocious- from sweaty, smelly, nastiness in one room, to parkas in the next.  They measure their alcohol pours a bit on the stingy side, and while the food is okay, it all seems reheated and is uninventive and underwhelming.  There is a nicer dining option upstairs, but the tables are mixed in with the bar area, and the space is really small for everything going on, so you're going to enjoy your meal with someone's ass in your face and a non-stop flow of traffic.Overall,  MAYBE stop in for a pint for historic reasons- or just walk in, walk around, and get out to go somewhere less like a theme park.  There are boat loads of historic places in London, it's not enough of a selling point to make it worth the hassle.

-w0FR1b3wXDnucqa59QSOQ.text: Perfect old pub right on Fleet Street. The Chocolate stout was outstanding.

pECOHdOHKDkPfR5gZ325pg.text: Great pub, good food, good history, and so many good memories here.  This is a great place to bring out of town guests to visit an historic English pub.  The food is good and they even serve a Thanksgiving Day meal if you are American looking for a place following the service at St. Paul's.

ziT1VzQS8Tjwvd-rfIZhbg.text: If you are a fan of the whole pub experience this is the it place. I have been there few times. When you are there it feels like you are in different time. The food is nothing special, but it is a great place for tourists.

k0W1Qq1lyfUZFUhkgHHFzA.text: Great pub, not too crowded or busy.  Interesting interior and very good beer.  The fish and chips was just ok however the hubbies meat pie was quite good.  Very old place to boot.

F_NYILaAtYdbYOHkJGaN-A.text: Cheeeeese. I love this place. There is not a single bad thing about it. The multiple levels and different areas of this labyrinth of a pub. They serve a good mix of beers and have McCoy's chips. One of the best nights since I've been in London came to fruition courtesy of the Cheese. I prefer the down-downstairs part as there is an easy access bar and tables. My only recommendation is for YOU to go here. It is just fantastic and why I love going out on Fleet Street. This is definitely the place you go after you've already had a couple. This is where you spend the remainder of your night till they kick you out and you find somewhere still open nearby.

mLUrCAI-dhxRAVxgpqB6DQ.text: You know how sometimes you just want to feel like a 65 year old man who's lived in London his whole life?...this place makes me feel that way.  Its as traditional as "traditional english pub" can get.  And the biggest plus is that its cheap!  Some pints are less than 2 quid.  Its tucked away making it great for just hanging out and conversing with friends.

N8gtQtriN-rCTTWS7xM_7A.text: A great place to drink or eat. Foreign tourists will love the sense of raw Englishness and history you get in there. And Brits will love it too, because drinking in there is like drinking in a timewarp - it really does take you back to 18th and 19th century London in a very authentic way and without coming across as kitsch or overly romanticised.The pub even seems to reek of coalfire smoke, which really added to the ambience for me. And the dark, heavy wood panels and tables take you back to a much browner period of history.The sausages are good, as is the rarebit.The beer is good, I thought a bit pricey, but that's to be expected from a pub right on the Strand.I love the historical info next to the stuffed parrot too. It was a pub pet famous for its proficiency in swearing, which, when it died, received obituaries in hundreds of papers worldwide. Utterly bizarre.

6wgDyK3T2ODDjy76L_rn-A.text: Try not to go here when already drunk and locate someone. It's really difficult. And mind your head!You've got to love somewhere that has a wine list of two: red, or white. The place is great: it's full of history, nooks and crannies, tons of seating space, standing space, eating space, getting lost space... Olde and Englishe and a perfect place for a pint or five.

d_3GITotASb6CdmL15T2gQ.text: This is everything you really want an English pub to be: a pub with character, history, cave-like rooms, a little bit of grime. The sign underneath says it all - "Rebuilt in 1667". That's right, as in, there was another pub here even before this one, a mere 343 years ago. Great atmosphere, reasonably priced Samuel Smith beers (amongst others) on tap, and they even serve bar food, which is of decent quality if you've had a few pints. Authentically charming, which is a rarity, I think.

Eo29VOz-Yaud3Xp0Im4yeg.text: This has got to be one of the best pubs in London. Mostly for its "olde worlde" charm and the fact it is hundreds of years old. You can't help feel like you are going back in time when you walk through the door!It has some great history to it and considering its tucked down a little side alley, you would never think its as big as it is! It's massive! Multiple different rooms and bars, a huge cellar bar, restaurants, saloon bar etc.The staff all seemed nice and being a Samuel Smith pub the drinks are very well priced too!A mate of mine recommended a new iPhone pub-finder app called "Smith Finder" bit.ly/TxB5ki that features this pub in it and loads more like it. Great for doing a bit of a pub crawl around London.

yPgDlWw3C4Rf42jMXRDKbQ.text: As a tradition, everyone at my work goes for a slice of the Cheese every year after a service in nearby St. Paul's Cathedral. And it's the best bit of the day.Tucked away from Fleet Street, this not-so-secret secret is a real treat. A pub with huge character, the cosy interior, dim lighting and log fire set the mood for a long night of boozy story-telling and, if it takes your fancy, a game of hide and seek. Unless you're as mature as the Cheese and don't do childish games anymore.The downstairs area has its own bar and with a good selection of tipples as well as the usual bar snacks, you can easily wile away the hours without even realising where the time has gone.Time for another trip to the Cheese. Anyone?

kLcaAue6pVhOqm0f2gcTeQ.text: If History and experiencing a friendly and classic London Pub is on your "to do" list.  This is a must stop.   Located in the Central London area, it is near many significant attractions.  Have a pint, maybe two... enjoy the history and the patrons.

-Ov2bGDvK_SRCPGtE-dBhA.text: Ye Olde is definitely an old tourist trap. In fact, I think Ye Olde is the the Disneyland of pubs in London. They have a not so subtle gift shop right by the front entrance.  But who cares?  After all, it is the oldest and possibly the most interesting pub in London and you just have to check it out (like Disneyland). Right outside the entrance is a sign chronicling its 400 years of history with the ruling kings.  (It puts the McDonald's "billion served" sign to shame.) It is rumored that Shakespeare hung out here.  To think all the drunks, scandals, and pub fights that occurred there over the hundreds of years, it's amazing that Ye Olde is still in business.  Beyond it's history, the pub also has an interesting floor plan.  It has multiple floors which are below ground.  (It must have been a conveniently cool place to hang during the air raids of WWII.)  each floor has tables and benches.  The pub also serves food but my local friends tell me it's expensive and not great.  Ye Olde also has its own beers too, but I wouldn't trek to Fleet Street just for their brew.  I would, however, go for the history and the ambiance.  Cheers!

8J4dBoItRRa8_GUp-jA4bw.text: This is the greatest pub in London and my favorite pub anywhere . . . Anywhere! Truly an amazing place, located on London's famed Fleet Street, just a half mile from St. Paul's Cathedral.  Originally opened as a pub in 1538, it burned down in 1666 during the great fire of London, and then reopened in 1667, as it has since remained.  Where else can you sit among the ghosts of such notable regulars as Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, Alfred Tennyson,  W. B. Yeats, Benjamin Franklin, Samuel Johnson, Mark Twain and Charles Dickens,  to name just a few.The interior consists of a maze of different rooms, a chop house, numerous bars,  spiral staircases, narrow passageways, coal fireplaces and a variety of antique grandfather clocks throughout.  One of the most interesting rooms is the cellar, with its vaulted white ceilings  and white stone floors.  It is believed that this was originally a guest house belonging to a 13th century Carmelite Monastery which used to occupy this site. It is amazing how big this place is once inside, as it seems unassumingly small from the main entrance.    Part of the charm of the Cheshire is that it lacks natural lighting, giving it that gloomy aura of centuries past.The food and drink offered is better than average 'pub fare',  but the reason to visit is for the history and charm of the Cheshire.  It really is a mandatory stop for all who visit London.  Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese gets my patented 4 thumbs up!!!

_Jf3s4o5QAY7hO5MW1d8zA.text: Charles Dickens' fave hangout? YES PLEASE! The staff is super cool here! Drinks are SO reasonably priced and what a cool piece of history the building is! I was going to give it 4 stars as the food is not too impressive, but the 5th is for the staff. I asked if I could pop open some windows and whatnot and they were so sweet and let me open as many as needed on the upstairs floor. I love this place. Just go!!!

zKpH2oaox1qvrpsRe6ZuwA.text: Being from the States, this place is hands down amazing. Great atmosphere and great company. This place holds a lot of history and should be visited by every grader schooler.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

zLG41Z4g76MprsvpXAeLww.text: One of the oldest pubs in the world. You can't go wrong. I also am a big fan of the Sam Smith pub. I believe there are better Sammy pubs in the city, but this one is the classic.

QJVx09eeOKl3hXv0FiHEMQ.text: incredible and amazing experience! The history, the atmosphere. My husband happened across the review. Must see!

7x6wHNEs0WtNFmoBNVkorA.text: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is a cool historic pub in the center of London. You'll find Samuel Smith on tap here. I had one half pint and sat in front of a radiator, which was the best part of my visit. It was so damp and cold outside, so having access to direct heat was incredible.I arrived earlier in the day, so it was mostly just older folks. Plenty of visitors though for early afternoon! I'm sure it's more fun at night (or with other humans) though.Bathroom is downstairs. Clean and tidy.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Half pint

GDMuEecBHwyk4LUN73qZVQ.text: I love this pub because of (1) our amazing waiter Michael, (2) the amazing dishes we had, (3) the real pub experience. Michael was the most friendly waiter I've ever had. Not only was he accommodating, he told you about everything from British beer to Parisian culture and made exceptional conversation throughout. The British beer had my head spinning but I could still taste the hearty mash potatoes and succulent cod from the cod and chips dish. This is a must go to pub because of the amazing service and excellent food and beer :)

8U4bKU7M190JGf2GkQS_JA.text: Cute historic pub that happens to have yummy fish and chips. The mushy peas are also good. Touristy, but definitely worth a visit.

Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

LvZA2J5UdmNbXxb-IDazkw.text: Cool pub. The place is huge there are tons of rooms and separate bars on all floors. I had a slow pour beer(my favorite) and my sister and I shared the fried goat cheese with a small side salad. It was tasty and came with a delicious sweet sauce on top. This is a great pub to grab a pint!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Goat cheese

QwPsLAHk4GujQrYwJthRxg.text: During our tour of London highlights, the guide mentioned as we past this pub that it was the oldest operating pub in London; on this site since 1538, but it was rebuilt in 1667 after the great fire.  With that type of history, l could not resist going back to try a pint.  We worked our schedule around and found a way back.  The pub is located off Fleet Street but down a walk way to the left of the pub's sign.  Don't worry if you go in under the sign, there is a map directing you to the pub's entrance. Upon entry, you are in a very small room; very low lighting and very rustic.  You can order here or go down the stairs where there are two more counters to order from in two separate rooms.  We ordered drinks first and then explored.The server in the first room was great.   I wanted to try something new and local to England.   He was very patient and explained and suggested something that was towards my taste.  Our next task was to find a place to sit.  The inside is arranged into small and medium rooms with tables for 2, 4, 6, or 8. The atmosphere is rustic and lots of stairs to get you to different levels.  I thought it was unique in how you could chose how private you want your setting.The beer was very good and produced by a local brewery.  They serve food but unfortunately,  I did not have time to order.  I loved the history and character of this pub and will definitely set a return trip when I find myself back in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. A place not to miss

19spKuiQ4AVrQoz9gmxCOg.text: Service at least with the young man that took care of us was great! Everything he recommended was delicious and he was pleasant Beers to order... the Taddy and the Bitter! Food to order.. sausage and mash, bubble and squeak and the toffee dessert for sure! The cheese tart was interesting but I wouldn't say a must order. Try to eat in the Chop room! It's the room with the adorable Parakeet and the table that Charles Dickens sat at!

cyqXRdWKM9rb_3iO1s_5YA.text: Rick Steve's audio tour took us here and of course we had to have a snack! The oldest pub in London! The best local beer in London. This was one of the best meals with had in London as well. The menu was VERY basic, but delicious. The sandwiches come with tortilla chips, which we found a bit odd, but they were very tasty! I recommend one of the sandwiches with tuna!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Tuna cucumber sandwich with delicious mini salad!

mJkEx0KKCZwwW6x2i_0SqA.text: Looking for a cut gem tucked away with locals - we'll join Charles Dickens on a time back in history as he frequented here !
