GiNz7PcoLUIa8n-A564oMQ.text: I've been here twice, once in 2015 and again this year.  The ambiance is amazing.  It's cozy and there are nooks and crannies everywhere.  So even when it's really busy you still have a feeling of intimacy.Oozes with history and one of the oldest pubs in London.  Charles Dickens wrote poems and proses and read them to anyone who would listen while sitting and having a pint back in the day.The food is classic pub fare and it's good.

iqEx21bZk8l8xzg9eJSJzg.text: Steeped in history that goes back to 1538, this is one of London's oldest pubs. It was rebuilt after the great fire of 1666.This place is like a labyrinth with six  levels with different bars and rooms on each level.Noted for being the frequent haunt of notable writers and poets; Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Mark Twain. It's said that Charles Dickens wrote the Tale of Two cities here...It was the best of times....'it was the worst of times.'If you are a tall person, over 5'5", you will bang your head on the low ceiling while negotiating the stairs.This is owned by the Samuel Smith brewing company, noteworthy for being one of the oldestbrewers in the UK from Yorkshire since 1758..As such you will find they have ample supplies of stouts and ales.This is where I discovered their Organic Chocolate Stout. If you like a Guinness you must try this beer. It can be found at most Total Wine stores.Very casual but you won't find a pool table or cell signal here and the menu is limited.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

g7tEobIHzeurvMjl0Fw6wg.text: Necessary stop after our ghost tour!  Bartender was so knowledgeable and friendly. Great suggestion to mix the raspberry beer and chocolate stout!  The interior is amazing as we were told it's been this way since 1667, with a cellar bar. Great find!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Fruit beer is always a must!

XZ3ejcW-5QwWxFHlulvEmA.text: You do not come here for the great beer but you come here for the history.  And for the history alone, they got a star.It is a classic british pub with small secular rooms and many floors (namely as you go lower).  They serve Samuel Smith beers on tap and darn are they good.  The history, however is fasinating.  Charles Dickens, Mark Twain, Sir Arthor Conan Doyle all use to call this place their pub.  To drink here and think of their novels is pretty awesome.If this wasn't so old and was just a regular pub, it would be a 3 stars.

GginJ6BKbSU_RtExAtMajA.text: This is a pretty interesting pub. Most of it is down the stairs and in the cellar, with pretty low ceilings as you're going down the stairway (mind your head!). I made the mistake of waiting in a queue for 15 minutes in the tiny bar upstairs to only be told to go down to the basement where they serve most of the food. My wife had the fish & chips while I had a Steak + Kidney Stew with several pints from the bar. The uniqueness of the bar and interesting ambiance make it a must try.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Steak and Kidney stew delicious food with chips

NNqa0QicAn8lQ-OFiwjOcQ.text: Stopped in to take in the history but was left disappointed. If you get a seat on the ground floor then it's excellent but don't waste your time on the lower floors. No character down there

6LOsWSeeu2MCEcy1K_12EQ.text: I can abide a tourist trap, but the sullen teenager serving beer at the front, I simply cannot. Not really worth a stop. The Seven Stars has a bit more character, and the service was friendlier.

GvvYhLJqZvnlLkhqZHSNbg.text: This is my absolute favourite pub in all of London. A treasured place since my 2006 study abroad, the Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is sure to delight anyone or everyone with the historical atmosphere. If you come for a visit this is the first place I'll bring you. It's known as being a pub from the 1400's but it burnt down during the great fire of 1666, therefore it was rebuilt in 1667 and has been that way ever since. It boast that Mark Twain and Charles DIckens wrote here, enough for any writer to want to grab a seat to think where and what they penned over a pint of ale. It's got a great selection of beer and ales. The best part is that they are cheap with great quality. In celebration of completing my dissertation for my Master's, myself and a fellow colleague had dinner over our favourite pint Alpine. She had the soup of the day (mushroom and vegetable) while I had the three cheese mac and cheese. Although fairly priced, we both were hesitate about ordering the mac and cheese. She hails from the South and as American's we've taken notice to how different the English make our comfort foods over here. Before I ordered I asked the staff if they honestly would eat the mac and cheese with them reassuring me they usually pick what they would only eat themselves on the menu. (it is possible they just gave me a line but I appreciated the humor) We were able to sit in my favourite section, in between the lower dinning room and below basement banquet seating bar. With our buzzers waiting to vibrate letting us know our food was ready we enjoyed the slightly echoey cave like clean dungeon setting with original lighting that wasn't too dim nor very bright. (if you've been here you know what area I'm trying to describe)Upon first glance at the mac and cheese it appeared to be a kind of casserole rather than what I was expecting. Nevertheless it was absolutely fabulous! The cheeses were all melted together, pasta perfectly cooked, and icing on the mac was this mixture of bread crumbs, pepper and garlic toping. It was the perfect size complete with butter for the roll and a light salad with a pleasant dressing made it more filling than the under £6 would have suggested. My friend's buzzer happened to be broken but the staff were able to bring her food out without letting it get cold due to the malfunction. It does get very busy in after work hours, but the beauty of this pub is that there are so many different places to sit and enjoy that it shouldn't be a problem. If you're tall you have to make sure to watch your head, it's over 400 hundred years old, before being able to accommodate everyone. It's a must visit pub whether you've lived all your life or are just passing through. It's also situated a couple of blocks above where The Black Friar is meaning it's a little out of the way to get too as Blackfriars station is closed for renovation. Enjoy it now before the Olympic rush will pack it to the point where you won't be able to breathe.

1kYubau7YBiTkgH_2GZWCA.text: This was one of the few places I had to go while I was in London.  The place is so old and you can tell upon entering.  There's an upstairs and then separate bar rooms on the first floor as well.  We went to the back bar, which was empty at around 5:30 but packed by 6:00.  It looks and feels old and dingy, which was its charm.  Thinking about the amount of people over the hundreds of years that have sat in the same seat as myself and drank was just an awesome feeling.  I got the beef and kidney pie and my husband got the spicy chicken.  I didn't see anything special about the spicy chicken; it was similar to any chicken at a bar you'd get in the states but the beef and kidney pie was very good!  I would've preferred it with mushy peas as opposed to regular peas and carrots, but other than that it was great!

_vavdUHh3coWu0Zcz31ZYw.text: This justifies the 'Olde' in its name, as there has been a pub at this location since the 13th Century, although the present building dates from 1667. The date gives a clue why: the original was a victim of the Great Fire of London in 1666. Mark Twain and Dickens certainly drank here, and Samuel Johnson lived close by, so he probably did too. The building is a wonderful warren of small, wood-panelled interconnecting rooms, all on different levels. It's tourist heaven, but it gets a mixed clientele of lawyers and office workers as well. There are two bar areas, with the main entrance, on one of Fleet Street's little side lanes, adding to the sense of atmosphere. The pub is tied to Yorkshire brewery Sam Smiths, and when I went recently they only had Best Bitter on tap, though it seemed well kept.. It ought to get four or five stars. But they really need to train their staff better: I was served pints with the largest heads I've ever seen (over two inches). This was largely because the sparklers on the pump were too tight (even though Yorkshire beer is normally served through fairly tight sparklers). When a friend (who is a head brewer at a different brewery) pointed this out, the barmaid said, 'what's a sparkler?'. That said, the staff were very willing to top the pints up to a reasonable level, when asked, and were generally very friendly. But an unknowing tourist would have received two very short pints. Sorting this out would deliver four stars, which it really ought to be able to earn, on account of its history.

pvCFp9k3EXut50VfGsmErg.text: I now know what it feels like to be a mouse, to have a lust for cheese and to inhabit an abode that is nothing but tunnels, alcoves and doorways. Finding a group of friends in here is not an easy task unless they have a homing devise on the. Unfortunately non of mine did, so I called them and they came out to find me.This unsuspecting doorway off Fleet street opens out into a rabbit warren of a pub, serving honest British basic food and Sam Smith beers. A round for 10 cost less that £30, thats £3 a drink... in central London. Bargain! This pub oozes atmosphere and a chilled out vibe, great for drinking wine and escaping the rain in the city or snuggling up with a hot date. It shows the people you take here that you really know the hidden gems of London... just don't tell they you found it on Yelp! ;O)

p5C2fdkz6Y5VZRtz8FbloQ.text: The best pub in London.  Historic, cheap beer and you're likely to get a seat.   The building  is so wonderful they can have sawdust on the floor and not be stupid.  This pub out pubs them all.PS I forgot to mention that they open the cellars at 6pm, so if you happen to be a-lurking you get your pick of the nooks and crannies.  Also, you'll get to bang your head on the stairs.  This is a very important ritual.  I've heard if you bang your head on the stairs at the Cheese you'll have a clear head No Matter How Much Cheap Beer You Drink..  Yes indeedy, this is a FACT.PPS Err In the Summer on a stuffy day the cellar is... even stuffyer.  The pub is next a court yardy area where you can go but  still.  BluegghhhhPPPS  This is a pub you go too to get slowly drunk and bond with people.  Do Not Buy Food here.  No non noonnooo...  Gastropubs have a whole new term all to themselves for a reason people and the Sam Smiths chain have worked out that they will sell food two groups of people,   no 1 Tourists who don't come back - and no 2 Drunk people - they don't remember..  Locals come here for the cheap cheap  beer, the lack of music and the four centuries of ambiance. These are great reasons.  Absorb these as your reasons before you go!!! NO FOOD.  Ok?  Good.PPPPs Ok, except chips and wedges.  You may have chips and wedges.

kOOp6SKNAwCql0_N4LVArQ.text: Amazing old pub with a great feel . It bleeds history and was once frequented by Charles dickens. The beers are cheaper then most other pubs in the St Paul's area and the serve their own unique drafts. There are multiple bars to drink at but the best is the one in the cellular.

QNNsx3e_kZWtO4u3QQXldQ.text: As my late granny would say, 'cheeses darlin', this place is AuLD!' In fact, Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is much older than my 99-year-old grandmother was when she passed, although it's hard to believe that anything other than Cher and cockroaches could survive for near on 350 years. Well go on then, YOCC! 344 and counting! This maze of a pub is sure to tick all of the boxes for your "traditional London pub" experience, with low ceilings, secret drinking spots, cosy wine cellars, seemingly endless stairways, and the smell of 300+ years of drinking den debauchery. Basically, it's amazing. Back to my earlier tangent, I can't tell you why or how granny could always make two syllables out of monosyllabic words like "AuLD" (or would it be "Owl-ed"?) But what I can tell you is that good 'ol granny Francis - built from hearty, corn-fed, mid-western stock - would have loved this place for all 99-years of her life, and would haunt the place in a heartbeat if she knew of its existence.

ZYen9RfZFXu2Q3n0_JpN1A.text: This is the best pub I have ever been to.They have cheap, yet delicious beer on tap.  It is right in the center of London.  There is not just history here, but you almost feel as if you are a part of it just by winding down the short stairs and into a dungeon-esque atmosphere.  There are all sorts of corners to sit in, and did I meantion that they have cheap delicious beer?If you can find this place off Fleet Street, it is your duty to enter.

oYgdFC9YkJhtnSQePZilwQ.text: Lovely underground banging decent ales, decent prices... it's a classic on the tourist trail as well as on the monopoly trail. It's a Sam Smith's pub, so Yorkshire prices. It's allegedly the oldest pub in London.And it's good. Not fabulous, but good.

y1dBSR67IPkXu-oDXV-40w.text: I did not expect this place to be what it was. We arrived early afternoon and were directed downstairs. Down very very low stairs. Where the cavernous cellar greeted us with a variety of table setups, nooks and communal seating. We settled on the very lowest level, hogging a communal table to the 4 of us as it was still rather quiet. As I expect the others will yelp about their own experience I'll only write about my enjoyment. From the downstairs bar I ordered a Cola. It came from a unique brew bottle and it was rather delicious. There is nothing better than a nice soda brew.I had a rather large breakfast and so I was in no mood for too much for lunch. I ordered from the fried section the battered calamari. I have a slight tendency to order calamari when I can, I just love the stuff. I've had good, I've had bad. This was some of the best I've ever had. It tasted as if they had caught the squid within the last hour. Fresh, the perfect tenderness, with excellent flavour. Even the batter was delicious, light yet crisp.If I lived in London I would frequent the Cheshire Cheese just for the calamari.

DAeOv7qNy34keZ_PP5SwyA.text: Everyone's stated the obvious and no one's mentioned the pie's, so i'll start and let others take over.  the pie is very tasty.

DtWk0vNrgMtzRv0_egOfNw.text: Last winter, I spent a week with some friends visiting pubs during the day and checking out Premier League games by night.  While we were in London, we happened upon this place and it was a gem.  There's quite a bit of history, central location, three different rooms (although seating can be sparse) and some great Samuel Smith beers on tap.  And they're reasonably priced: 5 pints for 11 pounds was the best deal we found all trip.

d80SyVsEemCP6hiiN3yICQ.text: A slice of Dickensian London, a few hundred yards from a number of Dickens' landmarks ( such as The Old Curiosity Shop). The atmosphere here is laid on with a trowel, with very dim lights and fires burning all year round. Also very cheap beer. Good place to bring visiting relatives from overseas or those easily overawed by "history", or to have a couple of quiet pints with chums; not the place for a raucous night out.

VY9895ZQS9IHnT9WUJUM2w.text: Where better to end a month-long hiatus from drinking than at a historic London spot like the Cheese?It's Sam Smith's, so I probably should have picked a beer instead of a glass of red, but I wasn't in a beer mood. And the wine was pretty good!I love the entrance, I love the maze of rooms, I even love the stink of booze in here. But only because it's the cheese.

MrQN7DIVnZA3ooQwVKcUDw.text: I do love this place, especially for the £1.94 Samuel Smiths :)But the food is good, the service was pretty slow in the restaurant but our server so was so great we totally forgave her and the ambiance is crazy, especially if your sitting in the downstairs pub...crazy loud, fun & a bit touristy.

V_sxSMNPFcxe4AMZCGiq5w.text: Amazing place, you cannot leave London without visiting Ye Olde, neat neighborhood.

Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

Lqi_DfM5OycGP5pxpRziHg.text: It's an institution, Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese.  You might think, 'What the hell kind of name is that?  It must be a gimmicky olde englishe London pub'.  But, in fact, you'd be wrong.  I mean, this place is on official maps of London for crying out loud!10 Downing Street... checkShakespeare's Globe... checkBritish Museum... checkLondon Eye... checkYe Olde Cheshire Cheese?  Yes, it's there on the map too.  Check.Compartmentalised into numerous drinking and eating rooms, with several bars, the Cheshire Cheese has old (at least I hope) signs that say things like, 'This room is for the enjoyment of gentlemen only'.  I stayed out of that room, not because I'm a woman but because it was at the entrance and I preferred to explore the pubs other, more cavernous rooms.This place is down an alleyway off of Fleet Street, offering it absolutely no opportunity for natural lighting; its interior is dark and dank with low ceilings. It's positively gloomy inside.  But, I say, the atmosphere is just perfect for some afternoon drinking on a miserable, rainy London day.

j4hGVd1XUA7lR4-ndCR-Mw.text: An excellent spot to enjoy a pint of your favorite Sam Smith beverage- mine is the Extra Stout- and conversation with a friend.  Be sure to explore this very old establishment.  It seem there are endless stairs and small rooms.

2VSq1_VzZV1FvwhiqDfuNA.text: If you come to London you have to visit one of the oldest dining establishments and pubs, right?  There's been a pub here since 1538.  That's 69 years before us Yanks even started to colonize across the pond!!    I consider it a huge bonus if you can sit under a painting of one of your favorite memes (Dr. Samuel Johnson), and he's not the only famous literary figure associated with the place, as it can also count Charles Dickens, G.K. Chesterton, Alfred Tennyson, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Mark Twain among it's patrons.   That is a very impressive list.You now another thing you can do?  Whisper an inappropriate joke about the menu items while there too.  Oh yes, Spotted Dick.  *titters*  By the way, I strongly suspect our waitress was NOT amused by my giggling at Spotted Dick with Custard, but she hid her annoyance well.  (You really can't take me anywhere.  I have the maturity of a 12 year old boy.)Anyway, all of this and I forgot to tell you that the food was delicious.  I had roast beef with potatoes and it was amazing- hearty and satisfying.  In fact, forkfuls of that was the only thing that kept me from being a full time giggling, Yankee jackass.  I'm trying to do better....I swear.  *giggle*

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

09DeCWSvU6JVOg4Gz54SSQ.text: Obviously coming into London there are a few things that one wants to eat, try, and see. You definitely want to see some history, you want to eat some fish n' chips and you want some good beers. Ye olde Cheshire has all of that, it's charming in a way that transports you to a different time. Once you walk in it's dimly lit along with candles on the table. The pub itself has portraits of old patrons and has shiny black painted walls. We were seated right away near the portrait of a patron that favored that particular part of the bar. Do go downstairs, it looks as if it used to be a speakeasy down there. The service is amazing, our waitress was sweet and informative. We ordered their organic line of fruit beers, the cherry was my favorite. Then we ordered the fish and chips, which came with mushy peas and scraps. She was nice enough to inform us that scraps are the pieces of the fish fry that fall off. Once eaten as a snack with salt & malted vinegar but was banned for being detrimental to ones health. Although the fish as so many have commented was under salted, we didn't mind adjusting it to our liking. Squeeze some lemon, add some salt and don't skimp on the malt vinegar. It was delicious, moderately priced and exactly what we wanted.

88U05HiRytj0Yv_0AmODFA.text: Absolutely the worst fish and chips I've ever had.Not only was it overpriced it tasted as if the oil was months old and they didn't even bother to take the skin off some of it. Tartar sauce was Heinz from packets. Simply terrible.Pathetic. Hopefully I don't get food poisoning

YxE0E91b80QOXT4YmWJbuA.text: Steak and kidney pudding wasn't as good as the sausage & potatoes I had on my first visit. We got there before 6pm, so we had to sit downstairs. You have to go to the bar to place your food order, and to get your food when it's ready. (They give you a buzzer) Dining room at the main entrance opens at 6pm.

NK9xrKxqAjNofm0m5uED3w.text: I'm almost tempted to rate the place at 3 stars, because the food was rather mediocre, but it could be my choice of a meal, so 4 stars it is.First of all, the place is ancient. I mean really old. I mean eating in catacombs kind of old. The historical value for me was that this (supposedly) used to be Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's favourite haunt. I certainly liked to think so, and therefore I've enjoyed a few beers there.The basement bartenders are a fun bunch (that's where you go for food, and for the catacombs), and the vibe is positively fun (so fun I've ended up with a stain on my tie, and had to urgently buy another one, but that's a story for another time :))Will repeat, when the opportunity arises.

U3pb2AI8_ykzEhvL8lmHRg.text: It's old and dungeon like. You'd be safe coming here if there was going to be an alien attack, as you are around 20 feet under ground surrounded by solid brick with no windows. It's dim lit and feels like you went back in time  They have the greatest drink I have ever tasted. Their bitter is absolutely wonderful. I was here 2 years ago and I have never forgotten it. It was the highlight of my second trip to London. I can't get this stuff at home, and I will always stop in for a pint every time I'm come back. I love the history. It's in a great spot on a beautiful road. And it's usually quite packed. Just mind your head as if you enter the dungeon. DRINK THE BITTER!

chzQVkXVIDMnLFzwVh5miA.text: Overall, not a bad place to have a beer. I think more than anything, one would go for the experience and for the ambiance, knowing that this is a place that has catered to people for hundreds of years. This is kind of an amazing thing, if you really stop and think about it. However, the beers themselves weren't phenomenal (though traditional) and the food was just ok. It can get crowded (with tourists) so finding a spot to eat and drink might be difficult. I stood awkwardly along the edges until I sat down at a table and made friends with the people (tourists) already there. I would say: go for the historical aspect. Revel in the fact that you're in an establishment that far exceeds you and your existence.

5YEh9Cof5VSC5jedTq49bA.text: It is hidden, but worth the visit for a different kind of pub to visit. It is thick with history and has hidden nooks and crannies with tables to sit back to enjoy the pint. It almost makes you feel philosophical sitting there.We had a ploughmans and a pint of ale, it was enough for two to split for a solid between meal bite.

GZuInglk06k37qtll829IQ.text: We came here not for food, part of it for beer and other part is for history. Since someone mentioned that Charles Dickens and Mark Twins were here, just to pay tribute to these great authors and their books of my childhood. Environment-wise it's a traditional English bar with 3 floors and each floor contains semi-secluded sections. Good place for young people to fly their spirits.

5XAFuWFaTXiwk-CmnJVytA.text: Book a reservation!  Had no idea they were needed but the place was fully booked with space only in the basement. Which by the way, is insanely cool. But it did mean that I wasn't able to order from the full menu which was a bit of a downer since I'd heard so much about the Welsh rarebit there.  I almost gave it four stars due to the barkeeper who was quite rude and even insulted my drink of choice - could do without that. UtRADJtejAnYdCL1HeBjAg.text: Very cool atmosphere. Rebuilt in 1667!. If only those walls could talk. We had the fish and chips.. very tasty. Local beer excellent.

FKNIX39wSIUVRFSPevy9zw.text: Apparently this place has been around for hundreds of years, and it's also one of the most reviewed restaurants/pups in London within Yelp. That got my butt down here, especially since the wife was craving fish and chips.They didn't have Guinness as I've been meaning to try it in the UK as some claim its better than in the states, but alas they didn't have any, as they serve their own stout.  Well, how was it? Pretty good.  The food was also top notch and you really feel like a person out of time when you come in here.  It's also a bit hard to find as you have to walk down an alley. It was a great London dinner experience and I couldn't have had it any other way. It might be a bit too dark in here for my tastes, but overall thumbs up!

AeOjKUFd3-BxHBR7ulTxbQ.text: Both a friend and Anthony Bourdain recommended we stop here for a pint and we were really glad we did. Before you even enter you feel like you are stepping back in time, and possibly having a rendez-vous with Sherlock Holmes. As soon as we entered the bartender directed us to go downstairs and to "mind our bog" (watch your head) because the ceilings are low as you go down the stairs. Really low. We made our way to the cellar bar and ordered a pint and chips then found a fantastic corner to enjoy them. It was a really cool pub with great atmosphere. The chips were on point and I hope to go again on our our next trip.

npgVCUjMRzxdgwy4C9r5eQ.text: Went here because of a recommendation from a friend. However, I would not recommend it. It's definitely a traditional pub and the atmosphere was added to experience of "traditional pub" but the food had absolutely no flavor to it and was somewhat cold. I got the cheese, onion, and leek pie and my mum got the fish and chips. We both felt the food had no flavor to it. The fish also had a lot of skin still on it.Waitstaff was friendly though.

6mwmTAz8GSQs48cC7mJmAw.text: This restaurant is about 400 years old. The inside is well maintained keeping the same style. The food was great and it definitely a great spot in London to get Fish and Chips.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

KjiOuFqhSdIEdNFpZInogg.text: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is one of London's most iconic pubs. This ancient establishment located on a tiny alley off of Fleet Street has played host to the famous, infamous, not-famous, and me!   Samuel Johnson who lived around the corner was a frequent imbiber here as was Charles Dickens who lived a few streets to the north. Mark Twain stopped in when he was in London - you get the picture - it has many associations with more than a few literary greats.  Tourists do find this spot or perhaps I should say their tour guides find it for them but there is still room for Londoners and frequent travelers to London as well. If you want to eat in their restaurant room, think reservation only.  But don't despair if you have no reservation .... it's cooler to eat at the self-service downstairs. You order at the bar two levels beneath the ground level and you will be given a beeper that will flash red to pick up your food when it is ready.  The pub food can be very tasty and don't forget to help yourself to the condiments.  I had a very good steak and kidney pudding accompanied by veggies and potato slices.  Naturally you would expect some good beers to be on draught and they were - I especially like the house ale. My only recommendation is that bubble and squeak is on the restaurant menu but not the pub menu. Aww guys - put it on your pub menu as well.The prices are very fair and the staff are friendly.  Sir Arthur Conan Doyle devised some of his Sherlock Holmes mystery plots here.  After a few beers at the Olde Cheshire Cheese, you might just come up with their solutions!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Steak and kidney pudding, potato wedges, and peas
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Grab an ale and your pub grub condiments
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Two levels down

3ndaso3fU72StxPa3U6ahg.text: I highly highly recommend ye olde Cheshire cheese for anyone who likes a pub and history. The building has multiple different room and the layout can be confusing to figure out where to go to get food.We ended up all the way downstairs in the cellar bar. The bartender was equity with all the history about one of London's oldest bars so you got a full show with your pint and bite.The meat pie that I had here was AMAZING and I believe this is a dish they change up. My plus 1 had the bangers and mash and thoroughly enjoyed it. It's pretty cool to sit in one of the favorite pubs of Charles Dickens. Perfect for lunch or stopping for a snack during your London pub crawl.

R_BZeMH4XBAGfZzqv1iKRg.text: Love this place. Historic and well kept. Your best bet is to head straight to the basement to get food; but, it keeps with the charm. Wonderful selections of beer and food. I really enjoyed my steak and ale pie.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

xSjg0IWfoVWwOPfgH2oX6A.text: This place is pretty awesome. Lots of personality and vibe, super old, historical, good hand pumped beer and good food. Seemed like there were more after work drinkers than tourists when we were there. There are lots of interesting rooms and corners to peak around, and don't worry there are a few different bars. Watch your head if your going downstairs, but the low ceilings add  to the charm here.

JfnP3u7uHDVO70yneY_ZbQ.text: Feels like walking into an episode of Game of Thrones. If you like beer, the Taddy Lager and the Wheat beer are a must have.

1rueRIYopc_dfD7uuVF88Q.text: This is another typical London pub.  The atmosphere is good.  The food is good.  The beer is good.  My wife had fish and chips and I had bangers and mash.  It was some of the best pub food we had during our visit.  Be sure to check out the pub's history before you go here.  It adds more charm to the place.  Legend says that it was re-built after the fire of 1666 and that a pub has stood in this spot since 1538.  Some of the regulars in the past have been Mark Twain, Charles Dickens, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, and others.

qwoTAkU4Q55cejWW6a94kw.text: In search of a great London pub, my wife led me to Ye Olde Cheshire Chese on Fleet Street.  Finding it was somewhat of a challenge, but well worth it once you step foot.  Nestled in the Wine Office Court, the setting is the home to some of history's greats.  This Cheese was rebuilt in 1667 (after the Great London Fire).  Once you step inside, you see the counter right away and you have your choice of libation.  I chose the Samuel Smith Old Brewery Bitter and it was awesome!  There are multiple floors, and pub food is also available.  But be careful and "mind your head" because you'll likely knock your head in the doorways.  On your trek downstairs, check out the wine cellars and relax with some true CAMRA (Campaign for Real Ale) good beer.If you've had a truly good time, I'd remind you to "mind your head" on your way out!  Check out the CAMRA sign, and the list of English sovereigns that have reigned since the Cheese has been open.  To sum up this experience, I'd somehow wish I never made it here.  Being back home, it's truly depressing to be so far away and searching for an equivalent.  One thing is for sure, I'll be back...

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Outside Sign
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Wine Office Court
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese

uy1_5l8NqrhOAQI_Cvy_4w.text: Went here whilst visiting London due to the historic cool factor. Hard to find walking with gps but we made it.  Husband had the chicken mushroom pie, which is now his nickname because it's just fun to say. It was yummy. I had a burger...it was ok but you can't beat the weird factor with good beer. If you are looking for a culinary adventure go elsewhere, but if you are just a tired American seeking a cool place to have a pint and say you have been here, do it!

aOfSuAxb3g4mIoPb9QbUSA.text: 5 stars from a tourist's point of view - this pub is as good as it gets and exactly what we were expecting coming to London.  And who can't love that name?!  It was REBUILT in 1667 (not est), due to that foolish baker on pudding lane. The first floor has a bar right when you walk in with sawdust on the floor and a wood fire burning.  There is a dining room to the left that was closed when we were there, so we headed downstairs to the pub area.  The ceilings were really low and there were cool nooks in the wall for seating.  We both got a cider and drooled over other's food.  There's large communal tables by the bar with plenty of room to spread out your tourist maps!

rLeBKBOX4LJJjKAD6645YQ.text: Like all Sammy Smith pubs the beers are cheap and the food is decent enough, but it's the historic feel of this pub that draws tourists and locals alike.From the alleyway entrance to the wooden tables in the second basement, the venue embodies the feel of an old London pub.  Whether this is your first or hundreth visit, the first thing to do is head down the small staircase to the basement areas.  Don't expect to find a table after 5pm Thurs - Sat, but you will never be alone if you slip down for a cheeky pint at lunch.I have impressed many visitors when I bring them to this pub for the character and history of this pub, though I have been assured by pub guru Hitesh P. that Ye Olde Mitre is actually older than this pub.Always worth a look and will undoubtabley be back for a pint.

ojKCos6N0FPDIft89KzWBg.text: This was our favorite pub in London.  The Samuel Smith beers we tried were all excellent, the prices were great (about 6 pounds for two pints, which was very surprising), and the history of the place and it's guests is amazing.  We really liked the cellar rooms.

zdfD6z8jWNfBp5QDuifZ-A.text: Walking into Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese you instantly get the notion of how much smaller the patrons of this pub were back in 1667 when it was rebuilt. Being 6'3 I find myself doing gymnastics just trying to get through the low hanging walls and small crevice-like doorways.This being said - my colleague Mark S. gave me a shout one afternoon after work and told me to come meet him at this 17th Century locale. It was a cool spot with mucho historical ambiance fuming from its walls. I became quite enamored when I discovered that it was a Samuel Smiths pub - - which immediatly drew praise and made the cheap pints flow much quicker. Cool place to hang out and enjoy a pint in the heart of St. Paul's. If you are into London historical locales - you have found the pub for you. If you are into having a cheeky pint with friends - you have for the pub for you. Go here and enjoy yourself, just please watch your head & step when moving about.

1mudMHxwHnp3Xa-2LQnRPA.text: What can I say about this place that has not already been said? As a tourist in London you have to pay it a visit for a real authentic piece of London (well post great fire at least). Well for me it's a great pub with lots of nocks and crannies, serving great beer and hot fresh food. The staff are friendly and the prices are very reasonable (especially as it's located in the centre of the City) If you go during the week for lunch ensure you arrive early to beat the queues!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

XmSK94JuCLf4rScL3luSgg.text: One of the coolest pub discoveris ever!It really old which makes it really coolGreat bar and really good food.Great ambiance.Nuff said

HZPICHS9ZiT-j-1KYxwVzw.text: I had a great time here. I was visiting London with my boyfriend and he loves taverns like this. The seating was underground in these catacombs and the age of the place was apparent. Next time I return to London I'll be sure to bring some friends with me and drag them here.The food was good, not amazing but decent. The cider was fantastic and that was really the point of my visit. I was kind of disappointed they closed at 11. I would have liked to have stayed there all night if they'd have let me.

8LvbVMoInVmez8VKr-0ZOA.text: The Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is a Sam Smiths pub on Fleet Street. It's slightly contrived name is justified by the history and decor of the place. There has been a pub on the location since 1538, being rebuilt after the Great Fire of London. Additionally it is mentioned in Charles Dickens' 'A Tale of Two Cities'. The decor is as one would expect from somewhere with this heritage. There is lots of wood paneling, pokey little rooms, and a slightly dangerous stair case. My favourite place to sit is the lower most room which has its own bar and looks like a cellar. As a Sam Smith's bar the drinks selection is very good value if a little limited. The clientele is a mix of businessmen, tourists and students. The staff are personable and efficient.A good pub with lots of character and a wonderful sense of history. If you're a tourist visiting London I'd particularly recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

ID0G2hjBvwN9_JHTzWGdEA.text: Oh London London. How I miss your pubs! My London college life mainly consisted of studying and drinking, so pub drinking inevitably formed a very VERY important part of my weekly (almost daily) agenda. Cheshire Cheese is absolutely charming and is conveniently located only a 5 minutes from my college library, so it was a regular meet up spot after lectures/classes. The atmosphere is adorable, and the vibe encapsulates London pub culture. Walking inside is like entering a wooden maze of low doorways and winding stairwells (definitely not a spot for the claustrophobic)....and nights are usually filled with local banker/lawyer types. The drinks are pretty standard (usually I just go for beer or cider) and according to my friends, the food is decent enough. Wanna re-live your Dickens/Sherlock Holmes fantasy? Come visit! And thank you Cheese, for all the memories and for providing me the warmth and solace of booze when I'm depressed from either the London gloominess or the fact that I have a 20 page essay due the next day.

2RJJwCKJEUZnC4xBu68TSQ.text: A totally English experience!! I am so glad our friends had recommended us to visit! It was so hard to find as well! I am always always going to be a fan of good old fish and chips! English grub, English beer...English 100% Nothing better out of life i'd say! I think I nicked about 4 saches of mayonaise and ketchup..you never know when it could come in handy.

TAz0HnHCLtoA4VuRizKPjg.text: This place is iconic.  It was a must see stop on my first visit to London.  It really plays with your head to think that people like Ben Franklin may have stopped here for a bite on his visit to the UK.  History alone is enough reason to stop here.  But, on to the food!The beer never failed to please in London, and Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese was no exception.  The entrance is down an ally off Fleet Street.  As soon as I entered, the bar was on the right.  I put myself on the waiting list and had one of many great beers in the UK.The wait wasn't long.  I was seated at a booth across the hall.  Before long, I was joined by an Australian couple (nice folks, we did the touristy talk thing until our food arrived).  The food really isn't the big reason to come here judging by my roast beef, potatoes, and Yorkshire pudding.  No great complaints.  It was fine really, but nothing special.  Unfortunately, there was no Yelp back when I was here (2007) or I might have tried some of the other suggestions I see posted here.  Still, I'm glad I came and I'm likely to come again.  The food is fine, the beer is great, and the atmosphere doesn't get any better!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Dining area to the left as you walk in the entrance.
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Roast beef, potatoes, and Yorkshire pudding.
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Roast beef, potatoes, and Yorkshire pudding.

nGKW6Lurq37ft-1nakA7sA.text: Great location.  Would recommend at least having a drink here just to experience this place. Food was good - not great.  We enjoyed the sticky toffee pudding.

-TOQXrrDNB_QQNj9ODax1w.text: As a Cheshire lad myself then I award 1* for the name alone and I award myself 1* for being able to find it.....If Pubs were Racehorse then the Cheese would be 'Red Rum'. Mature, full of character and never lets you down.It provides full on good grub (Steak & Kidney pie is delish) and a pint (or three) of Sam Smiths will see you right. I had not been here for yonks and was not surprised to see that nothing, abso-bloody-lutely nothing had changed. Awwe Bless. It's like a home from home and you get the usual eclectic mix of locals and tourists wandering in. We always used to use the Cheese as our 'meet up' spot. Rule was ... 6PM in the Cellar bar on any given Thursday or Friday night whenever you happened to be in town and it is setup such that, even when the place is packed, you feel like you have your own 'ickle' private niche. We have had some brilliant pissupz in here, you just can't knock it for that 'Feels like a proper Pub' effect. I also think this particular boozer was formative in my fascination with ceilings. Take a look up whilst you're there ... see the charring on the Oak beams? Could that have been from the Great Fire of London 1666 ?.. take a look outside and see the sign that says "rebuilt in 1667" Nuff said. This place puts the 'Story' in historyAs a side note .. many moons ago I worked at the John Smiths brewery in Tadcaster and the story behind the two brothers, Sam & John is fascinating stuff. Go WIKI it and, if you get the chance ...go to Tadcaster and do the brewery trip. Trust me.

cAhkyG1MWOnqdFuyZj9j8Q.text: One of the oldest pubs in London is a quirky, nooky little Sam Smiths joint selling cheap but strong lager and other own brand treats.More rooms than you can shake a stick at and as most of it is underground you're best off meeting friends in the usual spot, or outside the front door if you want to make sure you find them. It's old. Very old.. an ideal place to take Americans in London.The food isn't up to much. Cheap and fried for the main. You're better off without it to be honest, there are plenty of places nearby to fill up on first.

J5ddoqFi3XyW6WFuP7-_3g.text: Pubs don't get any better than this one founded in ~1664.  Dickens drank here!  #enoughsaid!!!  The food we saw come out looked great as well, but can't speak to it otherwise.  Still not a place to be missed if pubs are your thing!

IlIv8Q38WzoUXoPDcv0__w.text: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese (what kind of name is this) was on our checklist of pubs to check out before leaving our four month stay in England, and we finally hit it up this week!It's cool to grab a pint in a place that predates the country you're from, I can only say I've done that a couple of times. This place is clearly covered in history and that is definitely part of its appeal. Its charm lies in a very worn, classic environment. The stairs are chewed away and the whole place is a little raggedy, but in the cool way. This is a great tourist location if you're trying to experience a classic London pub while you're here. Honestly, there are ironically very few like this still remaining in London. Everything is owned my Taylor Walker, Wetherspoons, or Sam Smiths it seems. This, however, is a thoroughbred original London pub and should be visited just for the novelty of its originality!!It's enormous once you get inside and there are many places to sit on its multiple levels. There are multiple bars too, so that's a great way to control traffic.Definitely visit Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese while rolling through, it is not an old cheese factory as you mistakenly may have thought. Also a quick tip, don't pronounce it "YEE Olde...," pronounce it "THE Olde....," something I picked up while in England.

xb8K01y2BYm1y3vEKRYKYg.text: Oh you just have to go here. PG Wodehouse has been here, Charles Dickens has been here, TA so cozy and warm, it's such a PUB. Just go. But definitely prearrange with your friends to meet outside, because once you go in it's a maze with ting spiral staircases and you may never find them. So cool. Order dessert!

aqZ3x6Jy4y5MIVIs8pJ_LQ.text: Well its a pretty unique pub loads if history but the beer is expensive . The pub is sam smiths of tadcastar . In Durham at the Swan another of their pubs i pay less than two pounds for the same beer . Oh hell got to upgrade to a 5 star have managed to get a seat in the old bar . Just imagine this bit dates back to the great fire , Johnson and Dickens used this as their local :)

p4PPnrI_4EhlgZYyRJa4Hg.text: This is supposed to be one the oldest pubs in London, having been rebuilt just after the Great Fire of London in 1666. There has been a pub on this site since 1538, although the vaulted cellars may have belonged to a 13th-century Carmelite monastery. I would estimate that the shepherd's pie I had here certainly dated back a few centuries.... It's a wonderful place to go and have a drink - loads of small dark wooden panelled rooms on several different floors that seem to change location every time you turn around. I'd suggest dropping breadcrumbs when venturing to the loo, but the sawdust everywhere would mask them. My gripes are this: I was too cold in here (it was winter and we were in a room that did not have an open fire, as we wanted something more substantial to eat.) I was uncomfortable (they may look amazing, but 14th century wooden pews were not designed for bottom-luxury). The food was not brilliant (think school dinners). I would strongly suggest that if you have not been here before, then go and hang out where Dickens once drank, but don't eat here, and don't expect too much other than history, a sore bottom and a chilly draft.

Pr-wu12UFGa-aKQ03MrnTA.text: As a rule I generally both loathe and avoid establishments of any sort that contain the words "Ye" and "Olde" in their title.  Perhaps it's because I'm an American and have been to more than my share of "Shoppes" and "Parlours" for "Old Fashioned" "Cookin'" and trinkets and sundaes.  In America, words like "Ye" and "Olde" in a title generally foretell truly terrible experiences with mediocre food, the worst sorts of touristy junk and LOTS of fakey old-time charm.  Really, it's enough to make the gorge rise.And so, I find myself deeply confused by Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese.It's a pub.  It has pints of good ale and cider and bitters.  And because I'm American and know well enough than to claim to know anything about pints of ale, cider and bitters, I'll say that they seemed tasty enough, better than you get most anywhere in the States, but otherwise not particularly special.And the food was likewise perfectly fine.  The roast beef was tasty.  The yorkshire pudding was...yorkshire-y...and tasty.  I suspect that the gravy was right out of a jar, but that seems to be par for the course in London pubs, and after all the diner meals I've eaten back home, I can't quibble too much about gravy from a jar.So yes, the food was perfectly fine for a diner.  Or maybe for a pub.  Not special.  Just fine.  A solid three stars.But then there's the "Ye Olde" part of the Cheese.  It's impossible to mind the use of Elizabethan vernacular in the title when the dining room you're sitting in has clearly been in use since the time when people actually spoke like that.  This is the real deal.  It's old old OLD(E) in here, and you have no doubt whatsoever that you're actually sitting in the place where Charles Dickens or Samuel Pope used to sit and eat their roast beef and pick their teeth and talk.  And that, for the tourist looking for some of Ye Olde Londontown with their dinner, is pretty darn cool.So would I recommend that visitors to London seek out the Cheese?  (And really, you have to seek it out - it took us fifteen minutes just to find the entrance!)  Absolutely!  You're not going to have the best food of your trip, but you're certainly going to have a memorable meal.

wXdZOnoyr7qSZfOHt1krZA.text: Love this place. Great food and beer, especially for the price. It is open seating and it can often be hard to get a table. Additionally, most of the rooms are pretty small so getting a table in a good location (depending on what you're looking for) can be even harder. But when it does work out and you get a good seat, it's my favorite pub I've been to in London (albeit a relatively small sample size).Definitely recommend the stake and ale pie and the Ciders are quite good as well. Highly recommended.

7Fxk3ICohK0lfDtIgJQ3zg.text: I really liked the ambience of this pub. It's has strange floor plan and staircases made for people from the past (ie...when people were shorter) but it certainly adds a charm to this place.Apart from W9 beer which was ... well a good beer I had fish & chips and they were nice, crispy and ... traditional.They don't play music I noticed - which makes it a great place to meet up with someone you'd actually want to talk. It attracts mainly City folk but also some random crowd (City folk on a dress down day?) too.In fact - the play is longing for old knights shouting for a serving wench and downing ale by the cask.

bW3VInXXtMuYNVjSzBLeTA.text: Would be 5 stars just because of the atmosphere, but food took forever. You have to be ready to wait for your food in most pubs, especially "authentic" ones. The atmosphere in this pub is so cool and you can feel the history!  Grab a steak pie and a cask beer. Bartenders were very friendly in the cellar!  Cheers!

37hB4vKXYne6xnod8CHdvw.text: Great stop on a tour through London. Number one tip: Don't eat at the restaurant on the first floor, go downstairs to the bar! They have the same food except it's cheaper. And the downstairs isn't a grimy dirty bar that you might expect. It had a great casual atmosphere and we had a great time without even buying alcohol!Fish and chips were pretty good. The pheasant was so so. Lemonades and dessert from the bar downstairs hit the spot. The building is pretty cool to check out. The first floor is pretty formal, but then super narrow spiral staircase brings you down to several table areas on different levels before you end up at the main open area. It's a little overpriced, but go for the experience (and then spend the rest of your trip eating somewhere else).

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Fish and Chips
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Pheasant

C_aYPTj_V2iUxirJ3fonSQ.text: This pub was introduced to me almost a decade ago when I was told people had been going there for centuries. The place feels historic going in! You can just imagine Charles Dickens writing away at one of the tables (which, apparently he did)The food here is quite excellent, particularly by London standards. (No offense London) I really like their grilled sandwiches which go nicely with a cup of draft cider or beer, of which there's abundant variety. The many floors and many rooms give this bar a private and also spacious feel (seems contradictory I know, but go and you'll see what I mean). I went with a group of friends and they let us play quarters in the basement quarters in the basement til closing!

m3hwmUBhVsqs6tHD_A5Ysw.text: We originally planned to have dinner but the set up is confusing and it was really crowded so we ended up just having a drink in the lower level. The building itself is really cool with lots of different levels and alcoves. A hostess might help make things a little smoother, although perhaps that is part of the ambience.

NPy2Ec6rGQEMu3HZnoMTAg.text: The storefront is quite traditional, and the pub offers a historical ambiance augmented by the dimly lit setting and darkened wood. The staff is helpful and exceptionally friendly.I ordered the Steak and Kidney Pie which came with vegetables and chips. The dish to be centered around the gravy which was acceptable. All in all, the dish was a bit top simple for my liking and lacked layers of taste; however, the meal was unquestionably salvaged by the stout that I ordered to accompany the dish.I settled on a pint of Samuel Smith Extra Stout. The coloration of the beer was incredible. I was not able to resist temptation and ended up trying some of the head which was extremely reminiscent of cocoa. I allowed the rest of the head to settle and tried some of the beer; it was one of the finest stouts that I've ever had.

506QAkhXU8PP4h7Dc9-nBA.text: Nice place to stop off for a nightcap and obviously very historical. Not my favorite pub in London, but it's worth a trip just to have a drink in one of the oldest pubs in the city.

roXUv22j8AqyW1reX0WjOA.text: A little secret through the hidden alleyways off Fleet St. This place feels like stepping back 400 years ago. The bartender was amazing, the prices are decent (£8-10 for a main) and the food portions are generous. Come here if you're after an authentic pub experience.

VT7JUdmRbLPbXB0JaqdoRg.text: For the historical value, it's definitely a good stop along Fleet Street. But it's not a place I can see myself going to regularly. The rooms in the basement are all split levels and cavernous which is cool for the first pint. It gets pretty stuffy after the the second and third pint. The ventilation down there is not awesome. And my date was going downhill so the fact that there is no phone service meant I couldn't even nicely claim a friend needed to talk so I had to duck out early. I can't really blame the pub for that, but it did color my experience. The food was average, the drinks weren't badly priced, but any place that serves sticky toffee pudding (my favorite dessert ever) gets a happy face from me.

pggppvMyBzyrdSOODpT9kQ.text: Super fun old English pub where I've heard Dickens used to drink and write. looks like a great spot for groups to catch up over some pints, but was enjoyable for a tourist visit as well. The coolest thing about it is how old it feels. it's tucked away in a small alley with half of the bar in the cellar. there are so many small rooms, it feels like a maze trying to navigate it! The fish and chips! fantastic. get that. We also had the vegetable shepherds pie, which was okay, but felt mostly like a few carrots and peas underneath a massive amount of mashed potatoes. Go for the fish and chips and the ambiance. Super cool.

w83G39BR68GI9YoCIlL_9w.text: So, we had just arrived in London, it was stinking hot and after noon, we were jet lagged and starving, and our absolute first order of business after checking in to our hotel was to find a pub. Enter the Cheshire Cheese, just down the road, and a must do on my touristy list. Perfect.I love an old pub, and Cheshire Cheese is definitely that. Maybe the oldest in London, maybe not, but this place oozes history. And tourism, but as a tourist myself, I'll overlook that and just soak up the history. My sun-dazzled eyes couldn't take in most of the upper floor, as it was much darker inside than out, but in short order we were directed down the stairs and into the cellar area. As others have mentioned, watch the stairs and the ceiling. It's a miracle that my klutzy self didn't get a concussion or fall down the stairs! Ah, atmosphere. (Honestly, I did love it.)The cellar area is the very oldest part of the pub, so it was officially my favorite. Plus, it was nice and cool down there! We ordered a glass of wine, a beer, the Fisherman's pie (me) and the Cottage pie (my husband). The tables in that area are pretty much communal, so be prepared to share. The food came out relatively quickly, and while I'm somewhat suspicious that the mashed potatoes came out of a box, we were starving and the food filled the hole nicely. It wasn't gourmet by any stretch, but it was pretty solid pub food, and a good portion for the price, which is exactly what I expected.I probably wouldn't head back to the Cheshire Cheese for food, but would certainly come back for a drink and some more historical atmosphere if/when I'm in the area again.

-lWsPC6qJptUQR6mqgX8OQ.text: If you are coming for dinner, be sure to stand in the dining room to get acknowledged by the server first, then go grab a pint.  You will get seated faster this way.  If you approach from the East, it's worth the adventure to take the first alley just to see the sign to tell you to turn around.Fish and chips were delicious. Beer was delicious.  Server was del... well... he was exactly what you should expect.

KEzqkvM4JSJydE_MniIqXA.text: Classic old London pub with wonky floors and nooks and crannies everywhere. It's a Sam Smith's, so the drinks on offer are of a good consistent quality - I usually have the beer but recently tried a gin and tonic there and was suprised at the excellent value and taste.

wGkpGUJDCXHzoyr15HiCUw.text: I went to the Cheshire cheese, crossing London in the process, especially to dine here. The hours posted were incorrect. I was told wait another half hour-which I did. At the expiration of the half hour they were "open" but only for bar drinks and told me the kitchen would not be open for still another 30 minutes. Once burned, shame on them; twice shame on me; I got tired of waiting,left and went to a more customer friendly pub that was open. Disappointing... they should post hours correctly and state whether or not, when they open, it is for bar drinks only.

wuoO65wCLb9EH0UlbGnqHQ.text: This is one of the oldest pubs in London, as indicated not only by the Charles Dickens memorabilia everywhere, but also the low ceilings and tiny steps!  It is a really cool pub to drink at in the middle of London, as most other pubs look relatively similar (ahem wetherspoons) and are new and refurbished.  Cheshire Cheese has managed to maintain is old charms!  Just walking around, you will find rooms and little nooks and crannies that are hidden around the corner that have slipped your eyes earlier.  There are also wonderful dining areas upstairs, and the prices for the food are relatively decent!  I've been here three times and I still find new rooms and areas that I haven't seen before!  I ate dinner with my boyfriend here, and felt as if we were transported back in time!  There is a cozy fireplace and dim lighting, and large wooden seats, you can feel the history on those ceiling beams :)  The services was wonderful and everyone was exceptionally friendly!  There is another bar area downstairs where you can order cheaper, quicker pub food!  But be careful when walking down the stairs, I've hit my head every single time.  I literally have to almost touch my toes to avoid getting hit in the head. Cheshire Cheese is a great place to take visitors, and also for a relaxing night out with friends, as well as an intimate dinner with your loved one.  it is quite a unique experience, and definitely one of my favorite places in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

x-KoGidbAma4FqXQdQbecw.text: So this is supposedly the pub that Charles dickens drank at and is one of the more older pubs in London. Add on the fact that it was only a 7 minute walk from the hotel equals myself trying the place. The entrance is sort of hidden off to the side, kind of giving it a mystery element. As you enter and walk downstairs, because the ceiling becomes super low, almost guaranteeing that you will bump your head. There is about 3 levels to this place and I'll say about 10 beers (including one organic one which was good by the way) on tap. For food I tried their wings with sweet chili sauce (only 4 pieces but was good) and the cottage pie (can't remember the difference, but is similar to Shepards pie and was actually good). Overall a good pub to come to while in London.

bHTQOfuL0lEY1NsrLwYqtw.text: Went here on my most recent trip to London based on what I had read in guidebooks and online. It is truly a nice historic spot with good, reasonable pub grub and pints to boot. It's set back from the main street and once inside, it's a maze of rooms and staircases, which gives it real charm. I had a burger and it was accompanied with a salad and chips and all were quite good - fresh and filling. And I had an organic wheat beer (can't recall the name) that helped to wash it down. The staff I encountered were friendly and it's a place you could easily just go grab a drink if you aren't in the mood for food or just pop in and visit the various alcoves below ground.

Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom

o3ySaEPaUE6Nw9RhPTtL6Q.text: I have to say that this is my most favorite of the "olde city" pubs that are clustered around the central part of London. There's been a pub in this location continuously since 1538 - although it had to be rebuilt after the Great Fire of 1666. Don't miss out on this illustrious gem when you're wandering around the inner confines of the walled City. Frequented by Mark Twain and Tennyson amongst many other literary greats, referred to by Charles Dickens, Wodehouse and many others, the history here is quietly astounding. The ceilings are low, the air smells musty, the light is scarce. Nowadays on weekday afternoons you'll find somewhat smart-looking men with untucked shirts and guilty smiles knocking back a few beverages - trying to hide from the hamster wheel of corporate London. The fireplaces, mouldings and original fixtures are simply spectacular. Why only 4 stars? Samuel Smith Brewery owns the damn thing!!! No!!!! Most of the beers here are from the brewery and my insides just sag when I think of a lovely place like this being taken over by a large company. But such is life and change. What remains still charms.

aYL-nLL5c-tpZmzAfP4IoA.text: Amazing!! You have to go here! So much history and so many rooms and floors. It's really fun!! A must do! And great fish and chips and beer too!

cgk9e5wiNtNoxEnPIiAbJw.text: One of my absolutely favorite bars in London -- steeped in history and lore.  You can just walk around and smell the 450 years of pub history in the the stone structure and wooden bar. A big plus is that the place does not pander to tourists -- it is still genuine and passionate bartenders and local clients.  Good selection of beers heavily reliant on Samuel Smith.

I6CfDn38ai4JhxH2L4Rl1Q.text: The historical significance of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is worth a stop in by itself. A pub has sat at this spot since the 16th century, and the current edition was built shortly after the fire of 1666. There are a number of older pubs in the same area, but ya know, this one is called "Ye Olde". It really is beautiful! And huge. Lots of floors and little rooms. When you first walk in there is just a tiny little room to the right which is PACKED. Keep walking, there are plenty of other seats to be found. We sat down in the lowest level, which was really quite beautiful. We had dinner and a few pints. They serve Sam Smith beers, so predictable offerings. The menu is confusing in that it just lists all their beers, and not the ones they currently have on tap. Clean bathrooms, and great ambiance. The food was lackluster, probably some of the worst I have had at a Pub in London, but I'd still go back for a few pints.

6VRcAIFMlv-hlMs5OgQeIQ.text: I'd give it 5 stars but the staff seem annoyed by tourists.- They gruffly said the upstairs was closed, when all I did was ask if it was interesting.- They refused to serve our group  a final round, even though it was not quite 11 p.m. - by everyone's electronic devices.  The barkeeps said they had to go by "the time that's on the till"  and refused service and income.  Strange.As such, I'd suggest going there in the day or early evening.

Xsg26_Lsa64GCAwv0tbCew.text: A very cool pub (the spot has been a pub since something like 1644). It's got cool rooms you can choose from and it goes down 3 floors. Nice selection of cask ales and the food (calamari, nachos and ploughman) were all very good.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Somewhere in the halls

tyLrU9-MV54ZwgWUfauhKg.text: I love history, and this pub looks it's age which is great. But there are way too many tourists. Takes away from the charm, I think.

i70AlkqdC63ff7OqFmG1ug.text: Neat place.  Tons of character. The fish not chips are the best I have had on this trip.  Good portion of everything.  The down note is that our waiter was probably one of the original staff from 1667 and is miserable. That is unfortunate.  Otherwise, this is great place!!  You should try it.

photos.caption: Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese - London, United Kingdom. Fish N Chips

HEoCJHFJMs1RwgaDbMO4Uw.text: You can't quite get something more traditional and on trend than a pub like this in the middle of london. Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese is in an unassuming place, right bang in the middle of the city near blackfriars and on fleet street, hidden with an alleyway. It has a famous sign of its own, one if you walk past, you'll remember all the good times you've spent, or will spend in this very pub. Now I hit my head on the low beams and ceilings fairly regularly but even that hasn't tarnished my view of this place. I love it to bits.The cheese has such a great post work vibe but mostly its got these wonderful dozen or so different rooms, catacombs to explore. Best done with the finest ales and traditional food. Mostly I go because it has history and my my does it feel like it when sat on the wooden benches and being served by fine londoners.

8SWINOxHFV-oXF4gSjQaTg.text: Absolute best bar!!The fish and chips are amazing!! The staff is even better, very polite and social. Emma was awesome; chatted with us while the queue was slow; helped advise us of how how to get around.Will definitely drop back in on our next trip! As Texans, we were highly impressed with the food and service!

A53p0zUqygDl-aQW2C_8dQ.text: For the atmosphere (i.e. sawdust floors, low ceiling beams, and original structure) and awesome history? This pub gets an A+ from me and is a must for anyone who is visiting London. You could easily whittle away an afternoon, drinking in one of the nooks and crannies found in this historical pub. The food is traditional British fare (which makes it all the better for tourists who want to try fish 'n chips) but it certainly isn't gourmet or gastropub quality. As it's a Sam Smiths pub, it's pretty cheap and a decent place to meet friends. Never gets too crowded, either.A must-visit for anyone who's never been.

DXxqPB3Z0qJCpjEr-fEXIQ.text: I have been to the Cheshire cheese on many occasions. A go to pub when we have people visit from overseas, the pub is older than the US as a country which is so crazy but cool as I am American. The original pub was built in the early 1500s and was rebuilt after the Great Fire in the mid 1600s. Very quaint, all dark wood, upstairs and downstairs. Duck your head when you head downstairs, there are signs, but I cant tell you how many times I have smacked my head, you would think you would learn. The downstairs part of the pub is cellar like and there are booths built into the rock. If you are planning on meeting people and are sat downstairs be wary that the signal is really poor. The food is standard pub fare, fish and chips, pies, scampi. However, I have never found it disappointing always flavorful and hot. It is a Sam Smiths pub so there is not a huge choice, but I dont mind Sam Smiths beers so its never been an issue. Very cool pub, that has a very Dickens feel with solid food and cold drinks.

i1yMlUkrYA5k0QOOFdQfOg.text: Very atmospheric place with amazing history! Provides a pretty cool contrast of the modern streets around. The food it's great too, especially in the restaurant upstairs. My only moan, the seats are not very comfortable!

zw4GuxRf_Fbz56xi3Nf06A.text: Very cool spot.  Lots of history here.  Quirky, maze like place, rounded corners - more like a cave than a pub as you go lower.  I can I imagine Sherlock Holmes strutting about the place.  Reasonably priced pints, friendly service, cool location.  Don't eat here.  The food is entirely average, even by London Pub standards. Didn't see a lot of locals here - mostly tourists.  Come explore.

_LYusbcP3L97Zcefwc-ZNw.text: One of the most beautiful pubs I've been to. ,y style is very old and pre century so if you like that King George feel, this is it. Bar is built like a house with areas to visit on each floor . Best one of the base,met which dates back to the 13 th century. It was such a beautiful place and you'll meet some cool people!!

-jcvX0UWzppLd7EX2VDpQA.text: Don't bring the family or go for food. Fish and chips were soggy and had bones. Chicken dish with pine nuts flavorless. Services was terrible.

a01mjoq8VWvVLKupaJd4Qg.text: Very cool place to get a couple beers and enjoy a snack. We went all the way downstairs and it was very cool. Nice ambience and service. Many different drafts to choose from. A little expensive, but worth it for this institution of London!

_-TBcQw8dq2GcskrWuYqbg.text: A great pub, especially for a few pints after work. Beer's heaven on earth (Samual Smith Brewery) for every beer lover and incredibly cheap compared to London standard. Try the Alpine Lager, the bottled organic lager or a nice and tasty wheatbeer. The crowd's often a mix of Goldmann Sachs and Deloitte employees, as well as (American) tourists (the Cheshire is said to be the oldest pub in London and Dr. (Samuel) Johnson's house is just around the corner).

3rjNy7t7Vg9-SahH0oZWKQ.text: Charm in the CitySlightly over-run by City Boys giving their pinstripes an outing, nevertheless this pub has more charm than any other. The threshold of the pub is made of stone worn almost away over the years, the floors creak with every step, and the chill of the back bar runs spookily down ones spine. With cheap drinks and plenty of cosy seating this pub is definitely worth a try.

kadGc_rnNpUl3rMpdY5Qxw.text: Olde Worlde in a modern cityYes, it is crammed full of office workers in the evenings after work, but get there early to get a seat and soak in the wonderful atmosphere and explore the curious building. You can have a very pleasant drink whilst you do so.

5cIg1ZGHWCljphtvEjMp-w.text: Like everyone else, we wanted to go here, and it was Easter Sunday evening and not a thing in the area was open. Not knowing what we should be looking for, we noticed the pub on the right side as one enters was full, so we went in the back and had a pie and a pint. On the way out, we discovered the room on the right (which was Dr. Johnson's room, and had a nice fire and available seating). Bottom line: Ask somebody about the rooms in this place when you enter. It's worth the visit, not so much for the food, but for the history and the atmosphere.

umuDc4lxJq5NXvNqwQZoYw.text: Great atmosphere, the pub (from 1667) has countless little underground rooms with ales and lagers. The food is average.

VarKqyOtDWWGZlaJswGUQQ.text: Beer's good and so is the food. OK, it's attractive to (American) tourists but that doesn't detract from the ambience and you can normally find somewhere in the labyrinth of connecting rooms to hide away. Not a bad place to go for a pint after work.

x_CPYZwqtrMUPfk_1G057Q.text: I love this place. It's a place to pop in and have a cosy drink and fireside chat in after work one night. A place to have a pint with your Dad and talk about nothing. And a place to bring visitors and impress them with lots of facts. I can't believe how good the prices are, too. An excellent City/Fleet St pub that should be better known. But I'd rather keep it to myself!

Me29I8y3qZfm_hmygVa2jA.text: My one star is for everything bar the building itself. I would probably give the building four stars. But I wasn't there for the building.My gripe is this:There is only one ale on offer - Samuel Smith's Bitter. The only lager for sale is Samuel Smith's Lager (lager from Yorkshire?). If you want cider..you guessed it, Samuel Smith's cider.There is no Fosters, Stella, Carlsberg, Carling, Guinness, London Pride, in fact none of the familiar named ales or lagers or ciders, no guest ales, no Lambs, Captain Morgan, Bacardi, Teachers, Gordon's, Southern Comfort, none of the familiarly named spirits at all. It's so weird. They don't even sell Coke, or Sprite or any of those soft drinks we are familiar with. Everything is a cheap inferior substitute of the drink which you might have asked for in any normally run pub.I asked the girl behind the bar why, and she said it was to keep the prices down. Personally, I would be prepared to pay the extra and have my usual choice. Running a pub in this way is corporate suicide, surely.This is one of the oldest pubs in the country and a beautiful pub it is too, although extremely drab, and yet there is no choice for the drinker when they get inside. It may as well be a museum - after all it does feel like one.I came out of the Cheshire Cheese and crossed the road to Ye Olde Cock, where I was met with a selection of six different real ales and all the familiar stuff you would expect from an 'olde worlde' pub. The atmosphere was an improvement on the Cheshire Cheese simply because they seemed to care about their drinkers and what they want. Somebody had thought about the decor too. It was bright and welcoming and it felt good to be in there, which is everything the Cheshire Cheese wasn't.In summary, not a good place to go unless you're a teetotal historian interested in architecture. If you're in the area for the beer, try somewhere else.A bad experience.
